The authorities are urging anyone with information about the incident to come forward and assist in the investigation.
Such acts of vandalism have no place in our community and must be condemned.

“If anyone has information regarding this damage, please contact police on 101, quoting Police ref 614 13/08/17.” Condemning the incident, South Antrim UUP MLA, Steve Aiken said: “It is so disheartening to see the hard work of Randalstown volunteers being destroyed needlessly.
Anyone with any information, please contact PSNI on 101.
In an unprecedented move, both Showtime and HBO have secured the rights to broadcast the highly anticipated Joshua-Klitschko fight.
This rare collaboration between the two major networks will allow fans to watch the thrilling bout on either channel, catering to a wide range of viewers.
Both networks are gearing up to provide extensive coverage and analysis leading up to the showdown, ensuring that fight fans are fully immersed in the excitement surrounding this epic clash.
Both networks will use their own announcers for the bout.
Joshua, the British 2012 Olympic gold medalist, has fought exclusively for Showtime, while Klitschko has long had a deal with HBO for his fights.

The fight, which is expected to draw 90,000 to Wembley Stadium, features an undefeated champion in the big-hitting Joshua (18-0, 18 KOs) against Klitschko (64-4, 53 KOs), the long-running champion who lost his titles to Tyson Fury in his last fight in 2015.
Man City target Alexis Sanchez has no intention of staying at Arsenal.
Arsenal accepted a £60m bid, but the deal fell through when they were unable to sign Monaco’s Thomas Lemar as a replacement.

City remain the favourites to sign Sanchez, who is keen on a reunion with his former Barcelona boss Pep Guardiola at the Etihad Stadium, even though fellow suitors Paris Saint-Germain would be able to tie him down to a pre-contract agreement from January.
Sanchez's desire to leave Arsenal has been evident for some time now, with the Chilean forward seeking a new challenge and a chance to compete for top trophies.
Despite Arsenal's efforts to keep him, Sanchez has made it clear that he sees his future elsewhere.
His potential move to Manchester City would undoubtedly strengthen the team, adding more firepower to an already formidable attacking lineup.
With the transfer window closing soon, all eyes are on Sanchez as he looks set to make a decisive move that could reshape the landscape of the Premier League.
City's pursuit of the talented forward has been relentless, and it appears that Sanchez is equally determined to make the switch.
Arsenal fans may be disappointed to see him go, but Sanchez's departure seems increasingly inevitable as he sets his sights on a new chapter in his career.
Police have said they are keeping an open mind on whether a series of raids and attempted thefts in Aberdeen are linked.
A four-figure sum of money was stolen from Nigg Bay Golf Club.
The Bobbin pub on King Street and the Goals soccer centre at the Bridge of Dee were also broken into, but nothing was stolen.
Murdo's Bar on Caincry Road, Kings Links Golf Centre and a Spar shop on Ashgrove Road were also targeted.
Residents are urged to remain vigilant and report any suspicious activity to the authorities.
Detectives are working tirelessly to gather evidence and identify those responsible for the spate of break-ins.
Detectives want to trace three men who were seen in the vicinity of some of the crimes.
They are described as being in their 20s and wearing dark clothing.
It is thought they may have had the use of a vehicle.
Authorities say an anthropologist will perform an autopsy on a severely decomposed body found inside a parked car in Detroit.
Wayne County Medical Examiner’s Office spokesman Lloyd Jackson says a Michigan State University anthropologist is scheduled to conduct the autopsy Tuesday.
The body was discovered by a passerby who noticed a foul odor emanating from a garage in the neighborhood.
Police were called to the scene and upon investigation, found the decomposed remains in the car.
The identity of the deceased and the circumstances surrounding their death remain unknown at this time.
Investigators are working to determine how long the body had been in the vehicle and are looking into any potential connections to missing persons in the area.
The condition of the body has made it difficult to ascertain any immediate details about the individual, heightening the importance of the upcoming autopsy.
Neighbors in the area have expressed shock and concern over the discovery, with many hoping for swift answers to the unsettling situation.
The authorities have assured the community that they are diligently working to uncover the truth behind this mysterious and tragic incident.

The Episcopal Church of St. Simon in partnership with the local community has extended a helping hand to the Children in Crisis (CIC) organization, demonstrating their commitment to supporting vulnerable children in need.
Through various fundraising initiatives and volunteer efforts, the church has made a significant impact on the lives of children under the care of CIC.

Their dedication and compassion have not only provided vital resources but also brought a sense of hope and joy to the children in crisis.

The church's involvement has helped create a nurturing environment where children feel loved, supported, and encouraged to thrive despite their challenging circumstances.

This week, Instagram has been flooded with stunning travel photos that have captured the hearts and imaginations of wanderlust-stricken users.
From breathtaking landscapes to vibrant cityscapes, the best travel photos on Instagram this week have taken us on a virtual journey around the world.

The Bloomington Ice Garden has emerged as a powerhouse in the Hockeyville USA competition, making it to the final four teams.
The ice arena, located in Bloomington, has been a hub of excitement and energy as the team continues to showcase their talent and determination on the ice.
Fans have been flooding the arena to show their support for the Bloomington Ice Garden team, with cheers echoing through the stands during each thrilling game.
The players have been giving it their all, displaying exceptional skill and teamwork as they strive to bring home the championship title.

PHILADELPHIA — Alex Louin scored with 43 seconds left and she and Adrianna Hahn made 3 of 5 free throws as No.
22 Villanova held off Big 5 rival Temple 69-65 on Sunday for the Wildcats’ best start in 37 years.
Villanova is 9-0 to start a season for the first time since the 1979-80 campaign.

Temple (7-3), which led by as many as eight points in the second quarter, cut into a 10-point deficit over the game’s last six minutes, coming as close as 64-61 on a Tanaya Atkinson layup with 1:13 remaining.
Louden scored after a timeout and the Wildcats held on.
Hahn led Villanova with 19 points, her 39th game in double figures, Louin added 15, Megan Quinn 12 and Jannah Tucker 10.
Atkinson led the Owls with a game-high 24 points and a season-high 18 rebounds, her ninth double-double, Mia Davis scored 13 points.
The victory marks a significant milestone for Villanova, showcasing their strength and determination on the court.
The Wildcats displayed resilience in the face of Temple's challenges, ultimately securing the win in a thrilling matchup.
With key contributions from Hahn, Louin, Quinn, and Tucker, Villanova's balanced performance highlighted their depth and skill.
On the other side, Atkinson's standout performance for Temple demonstrated her leadership and scoring prowess.
The game provided fans with an exciting display of competitive basketball, solidifying Villanova's undefeated record and their status as a formidable force in women's college basketball.
FARMERSBURG, Ind.
- The residents of Sullivan County continue to seek justice in the cold case murder that has haunted the community for years.
The case involves the mysterious death of a local farmer, John Doe, whose body was discovered on his property in Farmersburg with signs of foul play in 2010.
Despite extensive investigations and efforts by law enforcement, the case remains unsolved, leaving many unanswered questions and a sense of unease in the tight-knit community.
Family members, friends, and concerned citizens have not given up hope in finding the truth behind John Doe's tragic death.
They continue to hold vigils, raise awareness, and push for authorities to revisit the case and explore new leads.
The lack of closure has taken a toll on the community, with many still grappling with the loss and the uncertainty surrounding the circumstances of the crime.
As the years pass, the determination to find justice for John Doe only grows stronger.
The Sullivan County Cold Case Task Force remains committed to solving the case and bringing closure to the family and community.
With renewed efforts and support from the public, there is optimism that the truth will eventually come to light, providing solace and a sense of justice for all those affected by this heinous crime.
A court case concerning the former chief executive of Shirebrook-based Sports Direct, David Forsey, and the collapse of the group’s fashion retailer USC has been further adjourned.
Forsey’s case was heard at Chesterfield magistrates’ court on Tuesday concerning USC which is also known as West Coast Capital and was adjourned until October 15.
Forsey is facing accusations of failing to notify authorities about redundancy plans for USC employees, which is a legal requirement in such situations.
The collapse of USC has raised concerns about the treatment of workers and the responsibilities of company executives.
The case has drawn attention to the importance of transparency and compliance with employment laws, especially in times of organizational changes and financial difficulties.
The upcoming court date will shed more light on the allegations against Forsey and the implications for both the company and its employees.
Apple has recently released iOS 11.3.1, addressing a critical issue affecting third-party iPhone 8 displays.
Users had reported instances of unresponsiveness on their iPhone 8 screens after updating to previous versions of iOS.
The update aims to rectify this problem, ensuring that third-party displays function properly on the device.

This issue has been a persistent concern for iPhone 8 users since iOS 11.1, with speculations suggesting that Apple's security measures, particularly regarding TouchID and FaceID sensors, may have contributed to the problem.
Some aftermarket companies have raised concerns that this could be a deliberate attempt to discourage users from seeking repairs from third-party shops.
iOS 11.3.1 is expected to be available to customers shortly.
Additionally, Apple is already working on a beta version of iOS 11.4, which is anticipated to be released to developers by late May or early June.
According to our report, this is an issue that dates back to iOS 11.1, and could somehow be tied to the company wanting to lock downTouchID and FaceID sensors for security reasons.
Or, as some aftermarket companies claim, could also be a way to damage trust in third-party repair shops.
iOS 11.3.1 will likely be available to customers soon.
Apple is also running a beta version of iOS 11.4 for developers, which 9to5Mac says will likely be out in late May or early June.
Indianapolis, IN - In a bid to support local food pantries and combat food insecurity, the 'Buy 2, Give 1' initiative has gained momentum at the Original Farmers’ Market.
The innovative program encourages shoppers to purchase two items and donate one to those in need.
The initiative has seen a heartwarming response from the community, with many patrons actively participating and contributing to the cause.
Volunteers at the market have been instrumental in coordinating the donations and ensuring they reach local food pantries promptly.
Every Wednesday, the Original Farmers’ Market gathers donations and delivers them to local food pantries.
This week, the donations benefited Horizon House, a day shelter connecting the homeless with resources and basic amenities.

“That’s an important step that people in Indianapolis can take to help us, help our neighbors who happen to be food insecure or those who are using social service networks to feed their families and to stay healthy with nutritious food,” Hogsett said.
The mayor has been working on several projects aiming to fight food insecurity in the city.

FILE - In this May 11, 2018, file photo, Philadelphia 76ers general manager Bryan Colangelo speaks during a news conference at the NBA basketball team's practice facility in Camden, N.J. Colangelo is denying a report connecting the executive to Twitter accounts that criticized Sixers players Joel Embiid and Markelle Fultz, among other NBA figures.
The allegations surfaced after an investigation into anonymous Twitter accounts that shared sensitive team information and disparaged players.
The incident has raised questions about professionalism and ethics within the organization.
Colangelo has yet to address the specific accusations but has emphasized his commitment to the team and its success.
The situation remains under scrutiny as the 76ers and the NBA community await further developments.
In a gripping turn of events, Bangladesh's Mominul Haque fell for a valiant 176 in the ongoing first innings against Sri Lanka.
The left-handed batsman showcased skill and determination, guiding his team to a formidable total before being dismissed.
Mominul's innings included a mix of solid defense and elegant stroke play, providing a strong foundation for Bangladesh's performance.
Despite his departure, Mahmudullah held firm at the crease, steadily accumulating runs alongside Sunzamul Islam as Bangladesh headed into the lunch break.
Earlier, Rangana Herath's masterful bowling display rattled the Bangladeshi lineup, claiming crucial wickets to swing momentum in Sri Lanka's favor.
The veteran spinner's early strikes put pressure on the hosts, setting the stage for an intriguing battle heading into the next session.
Mahmudullah was batting on 49 with Sunzamul Islam on 23 at the lunch break.
Earlier, Rangana Herath inspired Sri Lanka get back into the game early in the morning session.
The veteran left-arm spinner struck twice to dismiss Mominul and Mosaddek Hossain in the first seven overs of the day.
Bangladesh resumed the day on 374-4.
Mominul added just one run to his overnight tally while Mosaddek made 8.
Mehidy Hasan then counterattacked to keep Sri Lanka frustrated, but was run out for 20 trying to score a third run.
In a significant development aimed at easing tensions, India and Pakistan have agreed to a ceasefire along the Line of Control (LoC) in the disputed region of Kashmir.
The decision to implement a truce on the border, which has been marred by frequent exchanges of fire and shelling, was announced by both countries' military officials simultaneously.

The agreement, reached after discussions between the Director Generals of Military Operations (DGMOs) of India and Pakistan, is seen as a positive step towards restoring peace and stability in the region.
The ceasefire is expected to provide relief to the civilian population living in the border areas, who have borne the brunt of the hostilities for years.
The truce comes after a series of recent skirmishes that resulted in casualties on both sides, prompting calls for de-escalation and dialogue.

The move has been welcomed by the international community, with hopes that it will pave the way for renewed diplomatic efforts to address the underlying issues between the two nuclear-armed neighbors.
Eager to restart their lives and return home, many were hopeful that the truce would stick, but not confident.

GENEVA (AP) — The U.N. human rights office says 206 companies — mostly Israeli and American — are facing a review of their business practices involving Israeli settlements that are considered illegal under international law.

In a long-awaited report, the rights office said more resources are needed to handle the complex and unprecedented task of compiling what some critics call an unfair "blacklist" and a sign of alleged anti-Israel bias at the U.N.
The report comes after years of debate and controversy surrounding the issue of Israeli settlements in the occupied Palestinian territories.
The U.N. has been under pressure to take action against businesses operating in these settlements, which are viewed as a major obstacle to peace efforts in the region.
The review process is expected to be lengthy and contentious, with potential implications for the companies involved and the broader political landscape in the Middle East.
The 16-page report released Wednesday does not cite any companies by name.
It says the rights office has contacted 64 companies, but that it would not release any names until all 206 companies had been contacted.
MINNEAPOLIS (WCCO) — An 11-year-old boy is in the hospital after he was struck by a car outside of a school in Alexandria Tuesday afternoon.
The incident occurred during school dismissal hours when the boy was leaving the elementary school premises.
According to eyewitnesses, the boy was crossing the street in a marked crosswalk when a car failed to stop and hit him.
Emergency services were immediately called to the scene, and the boy was rushed to the nearest hospital for treatment of his injuries.
The Alexandria Police Department has launched an investigation into the circumstances surrounding the accident.
Authorities are working to determine the cause of the incident and whether any charges will be filed against the driver involved.
The school administration has expressed deep concern for the injured student and is providing support to the affected families during this difficult time.
GUATEMALA CITY (AP) — Authorities in Guatemala have raised by more than 130 the number of people officially missing from last month's deadly eruption of the Volcano of Fire.
The country's disaster agency says in a statement that the new figure is 332, up from 197 previously.
It said Wednesday that the revision followed a review of nearly 200,000 records and verifying lists of people living in shelters.
The Volcano of Fire is one of the region's most active, located to the southwest of Guatemala City.
Authorities have confirmed at least 113 deaths from the June 3 eruption, which sent superheated flows raging through small villages.
The eruption of the Volcano of Fire has left a trail of devastation in its wake, with entire communities being engulfed by ash and lava.
Rescue efforts have been ongoing, but the increased number of missing persons has raised concerns about the scale of the tragedy.
The authorities are working tirelessly to locate and identify those who are unaccounted for, while also providing support and assistance to the affected families.
The impact of this natural disaster will be felt for years to come, as Guatemala continues to grapple with the aftermath of this catastrophic event.
President Trump's administration is set to unveil a new opioid initiative that includes proposals to seek the death penalty for certain drug traffickers.
The plan aims to combat the ongoing opioid crisis, which has devastated communities across the country.
Under this initiative, individuals involved in trafficking large quantities of opioids that result in death could face the ultimate punishment.
Critics of the proposal argue that the death penalty is not an effective solution to the opioid crisis and may not address the root causes of addiction.
However, supporters believe that harsh penalties are necessary to deter drug traffickers and protect communities from the devastating effects of opioids.
"We have a problem of overusing," the official said.
Valley City High School Snow Week will be held Monday, Feb. 5 through Saturday, Feb. 10.
The event promises a week full of exciting activities and events for students and the community to enjoy.
Festivities will include themed dress-up days, snow sculpting contests, and a winter sports pep rally.
Students are encouraged to participate in the various competitions and showcase their school spirit.
Snow Week is a long-standing tradition at VCHS that brings the community together in a celebration of winter and school pride.

This free community event will consist of the VCHS pep band, cheerleaders, skits, the money jar-staff challenge, junior varsity dance team, and an introduction of all students participating in Hi-Liner winter sports and organizations.
More on this story can be found in the Feb. 2 edition of the Times-Record.
Dennis Edwards, the legendary lead singer of The Temptations and Motown icon, has passed away at the age of 74.
Edwards' family confirmed his death to CBS.
Edwards joined the The Temptations in 1968.
Though he wasn't an original member of the group, he sang lead vocals on some of the band's biggest hits, including "Papa Was a Rollin' Stone" and "I Can't Get Next to You."
He stayed with band until 1977, and later returned in 1980.
Edwards would have turned 75 on Saturday.
More on this as it develops.
FILE - In this June 25, 2017 file photo, Trey Songz performs at the BET Awards at the Microsoft Theater in Los Angeles.
Singer Trey Songz has been arrested on allegations of punching a woman at a party in Los Angeles.
The incident reportedly occurred during NBA All-Star weekend.
The woman involved accused Songz of striking her in the face after she spoke to another man at the party.
Law enforcement officials have confirmed the arrest and are investigating the matter further.
Songz, known for his R&B hits, has not yet commented on the allegations.
More details are expected to emerge as the investigation unfolds.
MINNEAPOLIS (WCCO) – The Minnesota Timberwolves announced on Wednesday they’ve signed guard Derrick Rose for the 2018-19 season.
The Timberwolves reached an agreement to bring back Rose shortly after NBA free agency started earlier this week.
He was originally signed by the Timberwolves as a free agent for last season back on March 8.
Rose appeared in 25 regular season games between playing for Minnesota and Cleveland last season.
He averaged 8.4 points per game and shot 43.5 percent from the field.
He appeared in all five of the Timberwolves’ playoff games against the Houston Rockets and averaged 14.2 points off the bench while shooting nearly 51 percent from the field.
Rose, a former NBA MVP, has been a key player off the bench for the Timberwolves, providing valuable scoring and playmaking abilities.
His experience and leadership have been instrumental in guiding the team, especially during crucial moments in the playoffs.
The Timberwolves are optimistic about Rose's return for the upcoming season and believe he will continue to make significant contributions on both ends of the court.
With Rose back in the mix, the Timberwolves are looking to build on their playoff experience and make a deeper run in the postseason.
Rose's presence adds depth and versatility to the team's roster, providing head coach Tom Thibodeau with more options to utilize throughout the season.
Fans are excited to see Rose back in a Timberwolves jersey and are hopeful for a successful season ahead.

OAKLAND, Calif. — Golden State forward Andre Iguodala will be out for Game 1 of the NBA Finals on Thursday night as he recovers from a bone bruise in his left knee that cost him the final four games of the Western Conference finals.

The Warriors said Iguodala, who was injured in Game 3 against the Rockets on May 20, was evaluated Tuesday and is making progress but still has the bruise and inflammation of the nerve surrounding his knee.
Iguodala's absence will be a significant blow to the Warriors as they face the Cleveland Cavaliers in a highly anticipated Finals rematch.
Known for his defensive prowess and playmaking ability, Iguodala's experience and versatility will be sorely missed on the court.

Head coach Steve Kerr will need to adjust his lineup and rotations to compensate for Iguodala's absence, likely giving more minutes to players like Shaun Livingston and Nick Young to fill the void left by the veteran forward.
Kevin Love's status for Cleveland remained unclear as he went through the concussion protocol after he was injured in Game 6 of the Eastern Conference finals against Boston.
He wasn't scheduled to attend media day Wednesday at Oracle Arena, where the Warriors host the series opener.
Drinking alcohol can give you more than bad breath.

A new study finds it can change the bacteria in your mouth and not for the better.Researchers say people who routinely drink one or more alcoholic beverages a day may have an overabundance of bad bacteria in their mouth, compared to nondrinkers.
It can lead to lead to gum disease, heart problems and even some cancers.

"Our study offers clear evidence that drinking is bad for maintaining a healthy balance of microbes in the mouth and could help explain why drinking, like smoking, leads to bacterial changes already tied to cancer and chronic disease," says study senior investigator and epidemiologist Jiyoung Ahn, PhD.Possible explanations for drinking-related microbiome imbalances, Ahn says, could be that acids in alcoholic beverages make the oral environment hostile for certain bacteria to grow.
Possible explanations for drinking-related microbiome imbalances, Ahn says, could be that acids in alcoholic beverages make the oral environment hostile for certain bacteria to grow.
This imbalance in the oral microbiome can have far-reaching consequences beyond oral health.
The findings suggest a potential link between alcohol consumption, changes in oral bacteria, and the increased risk of developing serious health conditions.
These results underscore the importance of understanding the impact of alcohol on oral health and overall well-being.
Practicing good oral hygiene and limiting alcohol consumption may help maintain a healthy balance of oral bacteria and reduce the risk of associated health issues.

Country music star Thomas Rhett has announced an exciting collaboration with pop sensation Selena Gomez on his upcoming album.
The unexpected pairing has generated significant buzz among fans of both artists, who are eager to hear the unique blend of their musical styles.

Rhett, known for his chart-topping hits and dynamic performances, expressed his enthusiasm for working with Gomez, citing her impressive vocal abilities and versatile talent as reasons for the collaboration.

“We cut 22 songs, which is way too many songs, and I think the next few months is going to be singing all those, getting them all mixed and then trying to narrow down which ones are the keepers.” In addition to Gomez, the new album features an appearance by Rhett’s father Rhett Akins, and Maren Morris, his duet partner on his current single “Craving You.”

NEW YORK (AP) — The latest on developments in financial markets (All times local): 9:35 a.m. Big gains in consumer prices and retail sales are sending bond prices lower and yields higher in early trading.
Bank stocks rose along with bond yields, but most other stocks fell.
The yield on the 10-year Treasury note rose to 2.51 percent Wednesday, up from 2.47 percent late Tuesday.
The higher bond yields sent high-dividend stocks broadly lower for the second day running.
Utilities, real estate companies and phone companies fell more than the rest of the market.
The Standard & Poor's 500 index fell 1 point to 2,336.
Investors are closely watching the strong economic data, which is driving the rise in bond yields.
The increase in consumer prices and retail sales signals a robust economy, leading to expectations of potential interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve.
This anticipation is impacting various sectors differently, with bank stocks benefiting from higher yields while high-dividend stocks are facing pressure.
Market analysts suggest that continued positive economic indicators could further influence bond yields and stock performance in the coming days.
The mixed reactions across sectors reflect the market's response to changing economic conditions, highlighting the interconnected nature of financial markets and economic data.
Police are continuing their search for two out of three suspects who robbed a McDonald's located off 152-Hwy and I-35.
The robbery took place yesterday evening, and authorities are urging anyone with information to come forward.
The third suspect was apprehended shortly after the incident, but the remaining two are still at large.
It's not clear how many customers or employees were at the restaurant at the time.
Police have said no one was physically injured during the robbery.
However, the suspects did manage to flee the scene with an undisclosed amount of cash.
Investigators are reviewing surveillance footage and interviewing witnesses to gather more information about the suspects and their whereabouts.
The community is shaken by this brazen crime, and residents are encouraged to remain vigilant and report any suspicious activity to the authorities.
Anyone with information related to the robbery is urged to contact the police department to assist in the ongoing investigation.
The safety and security of the public are of utmost importance, and law enforcement is working diligently to apprehend the remaining suspects.

British diver Tom Daley married Milk screenwriter Dustin Lance Black in May 2017, but the newlyweds just posted their wedding video online and will donate proceeds from the video to LGBT+ Switchboard and It Gets Better.
The couple met at a party in 2013, and Daley came out as gay later that year.
They made their first public appearance in 2014.
The two got hitched at Bovey Castle in Devon, England, surrounded by 50 close friends and relatives.
Black gushed, “When Tom and I met four years ago, I knew instantly that I was in trouble.
I knew I’d met my match.
The heartwarming video captures the intimate moments of their special day, from the exchanging of vows to the joyous celebrations with their loved ones.
The couple's love and happiness radiate through the screen, showcasing their genuine connection and deep affection for each other.
In addition to sharing their love story with the world, Daley and Black have decided to use the video as a platform to support important causes.

By donating the proceeds to LGBT+ Switchboard and It Gets Better, they are not only celebrating their union but also advocating for LGBTQ+ rights and providing support to those in need within the community.
Fans and supporters have flooded social media with messages of love and congratulations for the couple, praising their generosity and commitment to giving back.
The wedding video has been met with an overwhelmingly positive response, with many touched by the couple's love story and charitable efforts.
Jets rookie wide receiver ArDarius Stewart is currently on the road to recovery after undergoing two operations.
The third-round draft pick from Alabama had the surgeries within the past two weeks.
Despite participating in rookie minicamp last month, Stewart required the procedures to address his health concerns.

Head coach Todd Bowles reassured fans that Stewart is expected to be fully recovered and prepared for the start of training camp in late July, stating that the young player should be "good to go" by then.
Meanwhile, fellow rookie receiver Chad Hansen, a fourth-round pick from California, sustained a knee injury during practice, causing him to sit out Wednesday's session.
Bowles downplayed the severity of Hansen's injury, describing it as minor soreness rather than a significant issue.
The third-round draft pick out of Alabama had the injuries before joining the Jets, coach Todd Bowles said.
Although Stewart participated in rookie minicamp last month, he needed to have the procedures during the past two weeks.
Bowles says Wednesday that Stewart should be ''good to go'' for the start of training camp in late July.
Fellow rookie receiver Chad Hansen, a fourth-rounder from California, hurt a knee Tuesday and didn't participate in practice Wednesday.
Bowles says only that the knee is sore and it's not a serious injury.

MANCHESTER, England (AP) — Manchester City manager Pep Guardiola says Leroy Sane will be out for "six, seven weeks" after sustaining ankle ligament damage during the team's FA Cup win over Cardiff.
Sane's absence leaves the Premier League leaders short of attacking options in a crucial part of the season, with the Germany winger potentially missing up to 11 matches in four competitions.
That includes the League Cup final.
Guardiola expressed his disappointment over Sane's injury, acknowledging the significant blow to the squad.
The manager highlighted Sane's importance in City's attacking setup and emphasized the need for other players to step up in his absence.
Sane's injury comes at a challenging time for the team as they compete on multiple fronts, increasing the pressure on the remaining players to deliver consistent performances.
City will be closely monitoring Sane's recovery progress as they aim to navigate this period without one of their key players.
Update (8/14/17 at 3:30 a.m.): According to 911 officials, one person has died after the vehicle accident on West Pike Street early Sunday morning.

The incident occurred when a vehicle lost control, striking a tree along West Pike Street in Clarksburg.
Emergency responders quickly arrived at the scene and pronounced the victim deceased.

The accident resulted in a tree falling on W. Pike Street, which prompted officials to temporarily close the road.
Clarksburg Police along with DOH crews worked to clean up debris, direct traffic and work to remove the tree hours after the accident.

OTTAWA — Dozens of activists championing the rights of women and girls are gathering in Ottawa this week to make sure Prime Minister Justin Trudeau remembers his promise to bring along his lauded feminist credentials when he hosts G7 leaders at a resort in La Malbaie, Que., in June.

The Liberal government is making gender equality a major theme of its G7 presidency this year, including by pushing for measures aimed at boosting the economic empowerment of women and increasing female participation in the fields of science, technology, engineering and mathematics.
The W7 summit — with the 'W' standing for 'women' — that opens tomorrow is a way to ensure the voices of feminist activists from around the world are heard around that exclusive table.
Feminists are calling for concrete action, not just "platitudes," when it comes to addressing the systemic issues that continue to hinder gender equality globally.
They are demanding accountability and tangible commitments from G7 leaders to implement policies that will advance the rights and opportunities of women and girls.

The activists are stressing the importance of not just talking about gender equality but taking meaningful steps to address the existing disparities in various sectors, such as education, employment, healthcare, and political representation.
The gathering in Ottawa serves as a platform for feminist voices to push for real change and to hold leaders accountable for their promises.
The call for action is loud and clear, emphasizing the urgency of creating a more equitable and inclusive world for all.

NEW YORK — Mike Smith scored 20 points and Columbia kept Dartmouth winless in the Ivy League with a 77-74 victory on Saturday night.
Quinton Adlesh added 18 points on 6 of 10 shooting from distance for the Lions (6-13, 3-3).
Lukas Meisner scored 16 points and led with 11 rebounds.
Kyle Castlin also scored 16 and Patrick Tape had 10 rebounds.
Adlesh sank three 3-pointers early and Smith and Meisner each added another to help Columbia to a 21-12 lead and the Lions were up 39-27 at intermission.
A hail of 3-pointers by both teams opened the second half and Columbia led 63-54 midway.
In a tense final few minutes, Dartmouth fought back, pulling within 75-74 on a Brendan Barry 3-pointer with 14 seconds left.
However, Smith calmly sank two free throws to secure the win for Columbia.
The Lions shot 49 percent from the field, including 9 of 24 from beyond the arc.
Adrease Jackson scored 24 points and grabbed 14 rebounds for the Big Green (4-15, 0-6) who are on a nine-game skid.
Miles Wright added 19 points.

The vigil served as a reminder of the impact of gun violence and the importance of coming together to support one another in times of tragedy.
The community vowed to keep Godwin's memory alive and to work towards creating a safer future for all residents of Cleveland.

FORT WALTON BEACH, Fla. — Authorities say a Florida couple lied to their 13-year-old son about having brain cancer so they could use his fictitious illness to raise money for nonexistent medical expenses.

The Okaloosa County Sheriff’s Office says on social media that 34-year old Ginny Long and 47-year old Robert Long were arrested Thursday and charged with one count of child abuse and nine counts of fraud.
Detectives say the Longs set up a T-shirt fundraiser for the boy at his school last May and shared the bogus cancer diagnosis on their Facebook accounts.
A GoFundMe site was also set up for the boy.
The community was shocked to learn that the parents had allegedly exploited their son's health in such a deceitful manner.
Authorities are investigating how much money was fraudulently collected through these fundraising efforts.
The boy, who was unaware of his parents' deception, is now under the care of child protective services.
The Longs are awaiting trial and could face severe legal consequences for their actions, which have deeply troubled the local residents.

MOSCOW (AP) — Russian President Vladimir Putin says that Russia's economy has overcome a recession.
Putin made the announcement during a televised address, citing positive economic indicators and growth in various sectors.
He emphasized the resilience of the Russian economy in the face of challenges and praised the efforts of Russian businesses and workers in driving the recovery.
Putin highlighted that while the economy has emerged from the recession, there is still work to be done to ensure sustained growth and stability.
He outlined plans for continued economic reforms and diversification to reduce reliance on oil and gas exports.
The President expressed optimism about the future prospects of the Russian economy and reiterated his commitment to further development and modernization.

The Russian economy had plunged into recession under the impact of a drop in global oil prices and Western sanctions imposed on Moscow over its annexation of Ukraine's Crimean Peninsula and support for pro-Russia insurgents in eastern Ukraine.
Putin acknowledged that the Russian economy hasn't yet shed its dependence on exports of raw materials, but noted that non-energy exports have been growing.

The investigation into the incident is ongoing to determine any possible connections to other crimes in the area.

Trump's response comes after facing pressure to condemn Barr's remarks, which were widely condemned as racist and offensive.
It was the first time the president, who previously had called Ms. Barr to congratulate her on the success of her sitcom’s reboot, had weighed in on the fallout over her Twitter post.

In today's rapidly evolving digital landscape, the demand for skilled professionals is at an all-time high.

Part one of the series will delve into the root causes of the digital skills gap, examining factors such as technological advancements, changing job requirements, and evolving educational systems.

In part two, the focus will shift to strategies and best practices for upskilling and reskilling the workforce.

Finally, part three will highlight the importance of collaboration between industry, academia, and government in addressing the digital skills gap.
EDC will explore how partnerships and joint efforts can lead to sustainable solutions that benefit both individuals and organizations.
Stay tuned for this informative series from EDC as we work towards solving the digital skills gap and shaping a more digitally inclusive future.

French authorities are urging for calm following violent clashes in Nantes between protesters and police.
The unrest began on Tuesday evening when protesters took to the streets to demonstrate against alleged police brutality and social inequalities.
The situation quickly escalated, with clashes erupting in several areas of the city.
Protesters in Nantes clashed with police, throwing Molotov cocktails and burning cars and rubbish bins Protesters also set fire to shops and buildings in three poor neighborhoods across the city.
The clashes ended early Wednesday morning.
The Kremlin has vehemently denied allegations that it violated the US missile treaty, asserting its commitment to international agreements.
Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov addressed the issue during a daily telephone briefing, emphasizing Russia's adherence to its treaty obligations.

Peskov stated, “Russia has been and remains committed to its international commitments, including to the treaty in question.” He also noted that no formal accusations had been made against Russia regarding the alleged violation.

The controversy arose following reports from US officials claiming that Russia had deployed a ground-launched cruise missile, contravening the arms control treaty that prohibits ground-based intermediate-range missiles from both the US and Russia.
Despite these claims, the Kremlin maintains its stance on upholding international agreements and refutes any wrongdoing.
“Russia has been and remains committed to its international commitments, including to the treaty in question,” Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov said in a daily telephone briefing.
“Nobody has formally accused Russia of violating the treaty,” he said.

On Tuesday, media reported, citing US officials, that Russia had deployed a ground-launched cruise missile despite US complaints that this violated an arms control treaty banning ground-based US and Russian intermediate-range missiles.
Four parked cars were left damaged after a van crashed in Wokingham town centre, creating chaos in what locals describe as a notorious rat run.
The incident occurred on a narrow road, known for its heavy traffic and reckless driving, causing concern among residents and authorities.
Wokingham fire station crew manager said: "We attended an incident involving a young chap who drove into a parked car and took out three other cars.
"It's quite a tight road and people use it as a rat run.
"The van went airborne before hitting the other vehicles.
"No one was hurt and the police shut the road for an hour and 30 minutes.
"The crew made things safe and made sure there were no leaks coming from the cars."
The crash left a trail of destruction, with the van and multiple cars sustaining significant damage.
Witnesses reported a loud bang followed by screeching tires, drawing attention to the dangerous driving practices that plague the area.
Fortunately, no injuries were reported, but the incident serves as a stark reminder of the risks posed by reckless driving in congested urban areas.
Authorities have urged drivers to exercise caution and respect traffic regulations to prevent similar accidents in the future.
The cleanup and investigation following the crash are ongoing as the community works to address safety concerns in the town center.

NEW DELHI (AP) — India's government has asked WhatsApp to take immediate action to prevent the social media site from being misused to spread rumors and irresponsible statements like those blamed for recent deadly mob attacks.
The messaging platform has been under scrutiny after rumors circulated on the app led to a series of mob lynchings in India.

The government has urged WhatsApp to introduce more effective measures to curb the spread of fake news and misinformation, emphasizing the need for prompt action to prevent further incidents of violence fueled by misinformation.
WhatsApp has faced criticism for its encryption policies, which make it difficult to track the origin of messages.
The Indian government's call for action reflects growing concerns about the impact of social media on public safety and highlights the need for technology companies to address these challenges.

COLUMBIA, S.C. (AP) — South Carolina prison officials have for years blamed cellphones for contributing to inmate violence.

After a bloody riot at a maximum-security prison last weekend that left seven inmates dead, they find themselves once again asking federal officials to grant waivers and change laws to let them block the signals of these contraband devices.
In a shocking revelation, an inmate who spoke on condition of anonymity claimed that prison officers are complicit in the cellphone problem.

The inmate alleged that some officers turn a blind eye to inmates possessing cellphones in exchange for favors or money, enabling the illicit communication that can lead to violence and criminal activities within the prison walls.
This revelation has raised serious concerns about the integrity and accountability of prison staff.
Authorities are now facing mounting pressure to investigate these claims and take decisive action to prevent further tragedies and ensure the safety and security of both inmates and staff.
CONCORD, N.H. (AP) — A 130-year-old red-brick coal gasholder building in New Hampshire believed to be the last of its type in the country has been named to the National Register of Historic Places.
The round building with a cupola atop its conical roof was built in Concord in 1888 when coal gas was a major source of light and heat.
Over the years, the gasholder building has stood as a testament to a bygone era, showcasing the industrial heritage of the region.
Despite the decline of coal gas usage, the gasholder building's unique design and historical significance have earned it a place of honor on the national historic list.
The building serves as a reminder of the technological advancements of the late 19th century and the role coal gas played in shaping communities at that time.
The gasholder worked this way: Coal gas was pumped into a wrought-iron, 120,000 cubic foot tank that floated atop water.
The tank rose and fell based on how much gas was present.
The tank's weight provided constant pressure to force the gas out through pipes, where it was distributed to the public.

Neighbors are banding together to support each other and raise awareness about the importance of securing personal mail.
Community meetings are being organized to discuss strategies for preventing future mailbox break-ins and ensuring the safety of everyone's mail.

Connolly's hearing falls on deaf ears 14 June 2017 Dublin's Diarmuid Connolly walks away from linesman Ciaran Brannigan after he exchanged words during the second half Dublin's Diarmuid Connolly walks away from linesman Ciaran Brannigan after he exchanged words during the second half Diarmuid Connolly has failed in his bid to have his 12-week ban overturned by the GAA's Central Hearings Committee.

The St Vincent's clubman appeared before the Hearings Committee last night to appeal the Central Competitions Control Committee's decision to hand him a three month sanction for 'minor physical interference' with linesman Ciaran Brannigan during their comfortable Leinster SFC quarter-final win over Carlow earlier this month.
Despite Connolly's pleas and arguments presented during the hearing, the committee upheld the original decision, deeming the physical contact with the linesman as a serious breach of conduct.
The incident, which occurred during a heated moment in the match, sparked controversy and debate among fans and analysts alike.
Connolly, known for his talent on the field, now faces a significant period away from competitive play, leaving both his team and supporters disappointed with the outcome.

The decision by the Hearings Committee serves as a reminder of the importance of sportsmanship and respect for officials in the game.>

In a tragic turn of events, US officials have confirmed that a fourth US soldier has died following an attack in Niger.
The attack, which took place in the southwest part of the country, targeted a joint US-Nigerien patrol.
Alongside the American casualties, eight Niger soldiers and two US troops sustained injuries in the ambush.

The incident underscores the ongoing security challenges faced by US and Nigerien forces in the region.
The officials involved in the investigation have not been authorized to speak publicly on the matter and have requested anonymity.
This attack serves as a stark reminder of the risks and sacrifices made by military personnel serving in volatile regions around the world.

The officials weren’t authorized to discuss the matter publicly and spoke on condition of anonymity.
The tragic death of a man in a crash in Trigg County has been ruled as 'natural' by authorities.
The victim, identified as Moss, lost control of his vehicle leading to the crash.

Adidas AG is losing the executive who oversaw the German sportswear company’s U.S. turnaround.
Mark King, 59, is stepping down as president of Adidas North America, and will be replaced by Zion Armstrong effective July 1, the company said.
Armstrong, 43, has worked with King as general manager of the unit since June 2015.
During King's tenure, Adidas experienced a significant revival in the U.S. market.
He played a key role in boosting the brand's presence and market share, particularly in the highly competitive athletic footwear and apparel industry.
Under his leadership, Adidas made strategic moves to connect with consumers, focusing on innovative marketing campaigns and collaborations that resonated with the American audience.

Adidas also successfully rereleased retro styles like the Stan Smith tennis shoe and launched collaborations with hip-hop artist Kanye West, fueling a 35 percent jump in North American sales last year.
King’s time has been marred by Adidas being caught up in a federal corruption probe into college basketball.
An Adidas spokeswoman said King’s departure wasn’t related to the investigation, or any misconduct.

Chairman Natan Sharansky of the Executive of The Jewish Agency for Israel has issued the following statement following the weekend’s events in Charlottesville, Virginia: “I am deeply concerned by the expressions of antisemitism and other forms of racism and hatred exhibited at the neo-Nazi rally this past weekend in Charlottesville, and I am horrified by the death of a protester at the hands of one of the marchers.
These events are a stark reminder of the dangers of hatred and bigotry that still exist in our society today.
It is unacceptable that in the 21st century, we are witnessing such blatant displays of intolerance and violence.
As an organization dedicated to promoting Jewish identity and connecting Jews around the world with Israel, we stand firmly against all forms of discrimination and prejudice.
We must work together to combat these toxic ideologies and strive for a world where all people are treated with dignity and respect.
Our thoughts are with the victims of the violence in Charlottesville, and we call for unity and solidarity in the face of such hatred.
We must continue to speak out against antisemitism and racism wherever it appears, and work towards a more inclusive and tolerant society for all.”

LIMA, Peru (AP) — The son of former Peruvian strongman Alberto Fujimori is forming his own bloc in congress after being kicked out of the party led his sister.
Kenji Fujimori announced Wednesday that he and nine other lawmakers from the Popular Will party will henceforth support President Pedro Pablo Kuczynski.
Kenji's move comes after a bitter split within the Fujimori family, which has long dominated Peruvian politics.
His decision to align with President Kuczynski is seen as a strategic maneuver to gain more influence in the government.
The new bloc's formation is expected to shake up the political landscape in Peru, with potential implications for upcoming legislative decisions and alliances.
Kenji Fujimori's breakaway from his sister's party marks a significant shift in the country's political dynamics, setting the stage for a new chapter in Peruvian politics.

As the Fourth of July approaches, it's essential to remember that you're not a firework – don't drive lit.
Every year, celebrations for Independence Day bring people together to enjoy fireworks, barbecues, and time with loved ones.
However, it's crucial to prioritize safety, especially when it comes to driving under the influence.
Driving while impaired not only puts your life at risk but also endangers the lives of others on the road.
Alcohol impairs judgment, coordination, and reaction time, making it a dangerous combination with driving.
The consequences of driving under the influence can be severe, leading to accidents, injuries, or even fatalities.
To ensure a safe and enjoyable Fourth of July, plan ahead.
If you're going to be consuming alcohol, make arrangements for a designated driver or consider using taxis or ride-sharing services to get home safely.
Lyft is even offering a 20 percent discount on one ride to help partygoers make responsible choices.

Over the Fourth of July holiday in 2016, nearly 200 people were killed in crashes involving a driver with a blood alcohol concentration of .08 or higher, according to the Department of Transportation Before you begin to celebrate, choose a designated driver to get you home safely.
Taxis and ride-sharing services are also an option to help you get home safely, and Lyft is offering 20 percent off one ride to help partiers stay safe.
In many cities, local organizations are also facilitating programs that offer residents free rides home to keep the roads safe.
President Donald Trump's new immigration plan is stirring up controversy with its proposals on legal immigration.
The plan aims to prioritize highly skilled immigrants and reduce the number of family-based immigrants.

This move has sparked debates among lawmakers and immigration advocates, with critics arguing that it could negatively impact families seeking to reunite in the United States.
Supporters of the plan believe that it would benefit the economy by attracting more skilled workers.

CAPE TOWN, South Africa (AP) Dean Elgar hit an unbeaten 76 to anchor South Africa’s innings in testing conditions on the first day of the second test against Sri Lanka at Newlands.
Elgar’s battling knock allowed South Africa to go to tea on 147-4 after it had lost the toss and been asked to bat on an overcast and muggy Monday morning.
The left-hander lost opening partner Stephen Cook (0) in the first over of the day and saw Lahiru Kumara claim two wickets in one over before lunch.
Elgar's resilient performance steadied the South African innings, with Faf du Plessis providing support with a patient 40 not out.
The pair built a crucial partnership to stabilize the innings after the early setbacks.
Sri Lanka's bowlers toiled hard on a pitch offering assistance, with Kumara being the standout performer with his quick strikes.
South Africa will look to build on this foundation in the final session of the day, aiming for a substantial first-innings total to put pressure on the visitors.
In a devastating turn of events, the United Nations is facing a critical challenge in Yemen as resources meant for fighting famine are being depleted by the rapid spread of cholera.
The outbreak of cholera in the war-torn country has already claimed the lives of 923 individuals, with a staggering 124,002 suspected cases reported.
According to Jamie McGoldrick, the U.N. humanitarian chief in Yemen, the situation is dire and could worsen significantly by September, with the number of cases potentially doubling.
The battle against cholera has strained the already limited resources available for addressing famine in Yemen, further exacerbating the dire humanitarian crisis in the Arab world's poorest nation.
The diversion of resources to combat cholera threatens to disrupt the food aid pipeline to the country, putting vulnerable populations at even greater risk of starvation and death.
Jamie McGoldrick, U.N. humanitarian chief in Yemen, said Thursday that 923 people have died of the disease and there are now 124,002 suspected cases.
He says that number could double by September.

McGoldrick says battling cholera in the country beset by civil war has pulled resources away from work the agency is doing to battle famine and by September could cut into the food aid pipeline to the country, the Arab world's poorest nation.
Aid agencies have received $600 million of the $2.1 billion they estimate is needed to avert widespread starvation and death by treatable disease.

(Photo by Jamie McCarthy/Getty Images) WASHINGTON - Kim Kardashian West will meet with officials, including senior adviser Jared Kushner, at the White House on Wednesday to discuss prison reform, a person familiar with the plans says.
It's not clear if Kardashian West will meet with President Donald Trump.
The entrepreneur and reality television star has advocated for a pardon for a low-level drug offender named Alice Marie Johnson, who has served more than 20 years in prison.
Prison reform has been a key issue for Kushner.
Earlier this month, the White House-backed First Step Act, which would expand programs for prisoners and allow for more home confinement, was approved by the House Judiciary Committee.
Kardashian West has said she supported Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton in the 2016 presidential election, but her husband, Kanye West, has signaled his support for Trump.
The meeting between Kardashian West and White House officials comes at a time when the issue of prison reform has gained significant attention across the country.
Johnson's case, in particular, has garnered widespread sympathy and support, with many advocating for her release.
Kardashian West's involvement in this cause has brought further spotlight to the need for reform within the criminal justice system.
This high-profile meeting underscores the potential impact of celebrity advocacy on important social issues.
By leveraging her platform and influence, Kardashian West is using her voice to push for meaningful change in a system that has long been criticized for its flaws.
As discussions around prison reform continue to evolve, the involvement of public figures like Kardashian West serves to raise awareness and drive progress towards a more just and equitable society.
COWLITZ COUNTY, Wash (KGW) – Washington authorities arrested a retired military man Wednesday after he threatened to commit a “Las Vegas” style shooting and led them on a nearly 100-mile chase.

Christopher James Bleavins, 35, of Lakewood, Washington, fled Joint Base Lewis McChord Wednesday afternoon and sped off in a red Mazda after he was approached by military police, according to Charlie Rosenzweig, spokesman for the Cowlitz County Sheriff’s Office.
Bleavins' reckless escape triggered a high-speed pursuit that spanned multiple counties, endangering countless lives on the road.
The chase, which reached speeds exceeding 100 mph, involved multiple law enforcement agencies coordinating their efforts to apprehend the suspect.
As the pursuit unfolded, Bleavins displayed a blatant disregard for public safety, weaving in and out of traffic and narrowly avoiding collisions.
Washington State Patrol ended its pursuit at the Cowlitz/Lewis County Line, shortly after the collision.
Castle Rock police then spotted Bleavins driving faster than 100 mph about 10 miles south of the county line.

LONDON — A London museum has revealed that the remains of five archbishops of Canterbury were discovered inside a secret tomb beneath its building.
The Garden Museum posted a statement and video Sunday revealing the find, which was made more than a year ago.
The museum sits on a site that used to house the former St. Mary-at-Lambeth Church and is located next to Lambeth Palace, the archbishop of Canterbury’s London residence.
The discovery has sparked great interest and intrigue among historians and the public alike.
The hidden tomb is believed to date back centuries, shedding light on the rich history of the Church of England and its influential leaders.
The identities of the other archbishops remain a mystery, leaving researchers eager to uncover more about their lives and contributions to the church.
Garden Museum director Christopher Woodward says five archbishops were buried in the tomb, including Richard Bancroft.
Bancroft became archbishop in 1604 and played a major role in production of the King James Bible.
The remains of the others have not been identified.

MILWAUKEE — Giannis Antetokounmpo made a driving layup with 1.9 seconds remaining after Jabari Parker scored 12 points in his first game in nearly a year, lifting the Milwaukee Bucks over the Knicks, 92-90, on Friday night.
The game was a thrilling contest from start to finish, with both teams trading leads throughout.
The Bucks found themselves trailing late in the fourth quarter, but Parker's return provided a much-needed spark off the bench.

The "Greek Freak" lived up to his nickname, driving to the basket and finishing with a clutch layup over the outstretched arms of the Knicks' defenders.
The home crowd erupted as the Bucks took the lead with just under two seconds left on the clock.
The Knicks had one final chance to win the game, but their last-second shot fell short, securing the victory for the Bucks.
Antetokounmpo finished the game with a team-high 28 points, further solidifying his status as one of the league's premier closers.

MILWAUKEE — Shortstop Tyler Saladino has a sprained left ankle and has been put on the 10-day disabled list by the Milwaukee Brewers, who recalled shortstop Orlando Arcia from Triple-A Colorado Springs before Wednesday’s game against the St. Louis Cardinals.
Saladino jammed his ankle into second base as he took a throw from second baseman Hernan Perez on a force play in the third inning Tuesday night.

San Francisco Fleet Week, a highly anticipated event celebrating the maritime services, begins today with a thrilling lineup of activities and performances.

Apart from the military displays, San Francisco Fleet Week also offers a range of community events, including ship tours, military band performances, and educational programs.

Mayor Joe Smith and Indianapolis Metropolitan Police Department (IMPD) Chief Bryan Roach participated in a community walk in Fountain Square yesterday.

The US Federal Reserve announced today that it has decided to raise interest rates, marking the third rate hike in six months.
The decision to increase the target range for the federal funds rate to 1% to 1.25% comes as the Fed aims to strike a balance between supporting economic growth and managing inflation pressures.
Xinhua reported that the Federal Open Market Committee cited improvements in the labor market as a key factor in their decision.
Despite the positive labor market conditions, the Fed expressed concerns over persistently low inflation rates.
The central bank revised down its inflation forecast for 2017 to 1.6%, reflecting a more cautious outlook compared to their previous projection of 1.9%.

“In view of realised and expected labour market conditions and inflation, the (Federal Open Market) Committee decided to raise the target range for the federal funds rate to 1% to 1.25%,” Xinhua quoted Fed as saying after concluding its two-day monetary policy meeting.
The central bank acknowledged the continuous progress in labour market while expressed their concerns over weak inflation.

Fed officials lowered their forecast for unemployment rate for 2017 down to 4.3%, compared to 4.5% projection made in March, while their forecast for inflation rate in 2017 was revised down to 1.6% from their forecast of 1.9% in March.

The New York City health department says one person has died and two others have become severely ill after they contracted a rare infection called leptospirosis, which is transmitted by rats.
The deceased victim, a 48-year-old male, succumbed to the disease after experiencing severe symptoms including fever, muscle aches, and abdominal pain.
Health officials are urging residents to be vigilant and seek medical attention if they exhibit any symptoms associated with leptospirosis.
In response to the outbreak, the city has initiated measures to combat the spread of the disease.
Efforts include reducing the rat population in the affected area and conducting thorough sanitation inspections.
Additionally, the health department is actively educating residents about the risks of leptospirosis and how to prevent exposure to the bacteria carried by rats.
The city says it's reducing the rat population in the area and educating residents about the disease.
The New York Times reported that from 2006 to 2016, 26 cases were reported in the city; the Bronx had the highest number with eight.

50 Cent landed a big win in court recently, against two guys who claimed the rapper ripped off their idea for his hit TV show, “Power.” The two wrote a play all about the drug hustle and everything related to it, but at the end of the day, the judge says it isn’t stealing, because certain parts of the narrative just come with the territory.

The judge presiding over the case, Judge Analisa Torres, dismissed the lawsuit filed by two writers, Clayton Prince and Brandon Parrott, who alleged that 50 Cent, whose real name is Curtis Jackson, stole their concept for the successful crime drama series.
The writers claimed that they had pitched a similar idea to 50 Cent back in 2009, but were met with silence until “Power” premiered in 2014.

In her ruling, Judge Torres stated that while there were similarities between the play written by Prince and Parrott and the TV show “Power,” those similarities were not substantial enough to prove copyright infringement.
She noted that themes such as drug dealing, violence, and betrayal are common in the genre, and therefore, the writers could not claim exclusive rights to these ideas.
This legal victory for 50 Cent reinforces the notion that ideas themselves are not protected by copyright law; rather, it is the expression of those ideas that can be protected.

The ruling serves as a reminder to creators that while inspiration can be drawn from various sources, it is the unique execution and originality that ultimately determine legal ownership in creative works.
UNICEF's latest report highlights a concerning trend of increased illiteracy among young people in regions plagued by instability.

It says four impoverished African countries with a history of instability have the highest rates of young people unable to read or write — Niger with 76 percent, Chad with 69 percent, South Sudan with 68 percent and Central African Republic with 64 percent.

New UNICEF Executive Director Henrietta Fore says: "These numbers are a stark reminder of the tragic impact that crises have on children's education, their futures, and the stability and growth of their economies and societies."
The data underscores the urgent need for targeted interventions to address the educational challenges faced by young people in conflict-affected areas.
Without access to quality education, these individuals are at risk of being left behind, perpetuating cycles of poverty and instability.
UNICEF's call to action emphasizes the critical role of education in securing a brighter future for vulnerable populations worldwide.
DURANGO, Colo. — Durango officials say six new hotels that will add up to 450 rooms have been proposed for the city.
The Durango Herald reports the Durango Area Tourism Office expects the new hotels will be supported by the area’s tourism industry that’s projected to continue growing.
Tourism director Frank Lockwood says an additional 7,500 to 30,000 people are expected to visit the Durango Welcome Center after it began selling tickets for Mesa Verde National Park tours.
Lockwood says the office is also working on an agreement with Sky Ute Casino Resort in nearby Ignacio to promote the casino as a destination for conferences.
The office expects some people to stay in Durango while they attend conferences.
The proposed hotels are seen as a response to the increasing demand for accommodations in Durango, driven by the city’s popularity as a tourist destination.
With its scenic beauty, outdoor recreational opportunities, and cultural attractions, Durango has been attracting visitors from around the country.

The addition of these new hotels is expected to not only meet the growing demand for lodging but also contribute to the local economy by creating job opportunities and generating revenue for businesses in the hospitality sector.

The tourism office is optimistic about the potential of these developments to further enhance Durango’s appeal as a premier destination for travelers seeking a unique and memorable experience in Colorado.

The University of Wisconsin Board of Regents has adopted a policy that would create penalties for students who repeatedly disrupt on-campus speakers.
The new policy, approved by a vote of 16-2, aims to uphold the principles of free speech while maintaining a safe and respectful campus environment.
Under the policy, students found guilty of disrupting speakers or events could face disciplinary actions, including suspension or expulsion.

Regent President Drew Petersen emphasized the importance of protecting free speech on campus, stating that "the ability to express diverse viewpoints and engage in civil discourse is fundamental to the mission of our university."

The policy also includes provisions to ensure that all members of the university community, regardless of their beliefs or backgrounds, have the opportunity to express their opinions without fear of intimidation or disruption.

As Gary Sanchez steadied himself at the plate in the fifth inning Wednesday, it was not a tailing sinker that arrived from Houston Astros left-hander Dallas Keuchel.
It was an invitation.
A gaping hole on right side of the infield beckoned.
So with his hitless streak sitting at 19 at-bats and his continual pulling of the ball yielding only frustration, Sanchez did not unleash another violent swing.
Instead, he extended his arms as if he were a water skier hanging onto a rope.
Sanchez's decision to go the other way paid off handsomely as he slapped a single through the gap, driving in a crucial run for the Yankees.
His willingness to adjust his approach and take what the defense gave him proved to be a turning point in the game.
On the other side, Luis Severino stayed the course with his dominant pitching performance, shutting down the Astros' potent lineup with precision and power.
Mixing his pitches effectively and hitting his spots with precision, Severino showcased why he is one of the top pitchers in the league.
The combination of Sanchez's smart hitting and Severino's stellar pitching propelled the Yankees to a key victory, demonstrating the importance of versatility and consistency in baseball.

His second homer tied it in the eighth.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla. — The Jacksonville Jaguars are bringing back veteran linebacker Lerentee McCray.
McCray signed with the Jaguars on Monday.
The move reunites McCray with the team after he spent the 2020 season with the Jaguars.
The 30-year-old linebacker brings experience and depth to the Jaguars' defense, having previously played for the Buffalo Bills and the Denver Broncos.
McCray, who entered the league as an undrafted free agent in 2013, has proven to be a valuable asset on defense and special teams throughout his career.
His versatility and leadership on and off the field make him a valuable addition to the Jaguars' roster as they look to improve upon their performance from last season.
McCray has played in 50 games over five seasons, notching 28 tackles and three sacks.
McCray won a Super Bowl in 2015 with the Broncos and was a key member of special teams, where he played for current Jaguars special teams co-ordinator Joe DeCamillis.

Stuck in traffic this morning on your way to work?
Well you're not alone, but it's costing us a fortune.
A new survey has revealed that on average, employees lose 29.6 minutes of work per week because of bad traffic on their commute.
And that's costing the UK economy a staggering £203,846,153 a week, according to the survey by motorcycle insurance company Devitt.
The study further highlighted that the economic impact of traffic congestion is not just limited to wasted time and productivity losses.
The environmental consequences of idling vehicles in traffic jams contribute to air pollution and increased carbon emissions, affecting public health and exacerbating climate change concerns.
Moreover, the financial implications extend beyond just time and environmental costs.
Businesses suffer from delayed deliveries, increased fuel expenses, and decreased efficiency due to employees arriving late or stressed from their commute.

To address this significant issue, experts are calling for investments in infrastructure, public transportation, and flexible work arrangements to alleviate traffic congestion and minimize the economic toll it takes on the UK economy.
Failure to tackle this problem could result in further financial losses and negative impacts on both businesses and individuals.
U.S. 95 at I-15 is set to undergo a temporary closure as part of the ongoing Project Neon in Las Vegas.
According to FOX5 Vegas - KVVU, the closure is scheduled for the upcoming weekend to facilitate necessary bridge construction work.
The closure is essential for the progression of "The Main Event" phase of Project Neon, a major infrastructure project aimed at improving traffic flow and safety in the area.
During the closure, motorists are advised to plan for alternative routes to avoid disruptions.
While I-15 and the Spaghetti Bowl ramps will remain accessible, northbound drivers are encouraged to consider using Boulder Highway, Charleston Boulevard, or Eastern Avenue.
For southbound traffic, alternative options include Valley View Boulevard, Rancho Drive, and Decatur Boulevard.
Project Neon, now in its final phase, has reached 65 percent completion, with an anticipated finish date of summer 2019.
The Nevada Department of Transportation (NDOT) emphasizes the importance of caution and adherence to construction signs when navigating through the work zone.
I-15 and the Spaghetti Bowl ramps will remain open.
Alternative routes suggested by NDOT for northbound traffic include Boulder Highway, Charleston Boulevard and Eastern Avenue.
Southbound traffic options are Valley View Boulevard, Rancho Drive and Decatur Boulevard.
The road closures are needed for bridge construction as part of “The Main Event” for Project Neon, NDOT said.
Project Neon is entering its third and final phase, and NDOT said that the project is 65 percent done.
NDOT said the project is aiming for completion by summer of 2019.
Motorists are asked to use caution while driving through the work zone, use alternate detour routes and heed construction signs.

Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe has reassured Sri Lankan refugees that it is safe for them to return home.
Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe made the comments on Wednesday during a visit to Australia in which he discussed bilateral cooperation on combating people smuggling.

He encouraged refugees to consider returning to their homeland, where efforts are being made to facilitate their reintegration and support their transition back into society.

Wickremesinghe's statement signals a positive development in Sri Lanka's ongoing efforts to address the refugee situation and highlights the government's commitment to providing a safe environment for those who wish to return.

NEW YORK (AP) — A retired New York City school librarian has been sentenced to 15 years in prison for scheming to carry out gruesome fantasies of kidnapping, torturing and killing women and girls.
Robert Christopher Asch was sentenced Monday in Manhattan federal court.
Asch, who retired in 2013, was convicted in 2014 alongside a police officer and a former high school librarian in a case that involved chilling plots to abduct, rape, torture, and kill women.
The trio was caught in an elaborate FBI sting operation, where they were recorded discussing their plans in detail.
Asch's defense argued that his involvement was purely fantasy role-playing, but the jury found him guilty of conspiracy to commit kidnapping.
No one was hurt.
The convictions came a year after the headline-grabbing case of a police officer accused of plotting abductions and cannibalism.
A judge tossed the most serious charges after that trial and sentenced the ex-officer to time served for a misdemeanor.

Vietnamese villagers in a suburban district of Hanoi have freed 15 riot police who were held over a land dispute.
The state-run online newspaper Vnexpress reported Tuesday that three others managed to escape while authorities are persuading villagers to free remaining 20 police and local officials.
The standoff began Saturday when police clashed with villagers who allege their land was illegally taken for sale by a military-run telecoms firm.
Some villagers who were arrested have been released.
The villagers are demanding justice and fair treatment in the land dispute, which has been ongoing for some time.
Tensions remain high as negotiations continue between the authorities and the villagers.
The situation has attracted widespread attention, highlighting the challenges faced by local communities in land-related conflicts.
Authorities are working to peacefully resolve the situation and ensure the safety and well-being of all involved.

Lukaku, known for his physicality and goal-scoring prowess, has faced criticism in the past for not always delivering in high-pressure situations.

With the support of his teammates, coaching staff, and fans, Lukaku has the opportunity to bounce back and prove his doubters wrong.

Japan's World Cup send-off match against Ghana did not go to plan as they lost 2-0 in Yokohama on Wednesday to a side that failed to qualify for the finals in Russia.

The game had been touted as preparation for Japan's Group H clash with Senegal, but it will likely give coach Akira Nishino cause for concern due to the nature of the goals conceded in their final match at home before their campaign starts on June 19.

Japan remained on level terms for just nine minutes, as Tomoaki Makino was penalised on the edge of the area and Thomas Partey found the bottom-right corner with his free-kick – goalkeeper Eiji Kawashima failing to keep it out despite getting his hands to it.
The hosts struggled to regain their composure after falling behind, with Ghana looking dangerous on the counter-attack.
The second goal came in the 51st minute, with a defensive mix-up allowing Richmond Boakye to slot the ball past Kawashima to double Ghana's lead.
Japan tried to rally but failed to break down a resolute Ghanaian defense, with their attacking efforts lacking the sharpness needed to trouble the opposition.
Nishino will have plenty to ponder as he assesses his team's performance, particularly the defensive lapses that proved costly against Ghana.
With the World Cup fast approaching, Japan will need to address these issues quickly to ensure they are ready for the challenges ahead in Russia.
