“It was a tough one last year in different circumstances and I’m glad to get back here and put things right a little bit, although we were way off to be honest.
“We had 50 percent completion in the first half and there is no way you can win a game like that but we fixed it up in the second half.
“This is a hard place to come and they put us under pressure but we showed plenty of toughness to defend our line.”

Klopp says it was "probably a really bad injury.
That is bad news for us.
Oxlade-Chamberlain's absence would be a significant blow to both Liverpool and the England national team.

However, with the extent of his injury still unknown, it remains uncertain whether he will recover in time for the tournament in Russia.
Fans and teammates alike are hoping for a swift recovery for Oxlade-Chamberlain, but the road to the World Cup now seems uncertain for the talented midfielder.
A missing man from Ilford has been found dead, with the post-mortem examination revealing he died from 'extensive head injuries'.
Seyed Khan, aged 49, had last been seen at his home address in Thamesmead on 24 January.
He had left for work at A-Z Carpets in Ilford that day, with his car later found on High Road.
Mr. Khan's body was discovered at Ilford Cemetery on Thursday, prompting an investigation into his death.
Detectives have arrested a 30-year-old man on suspicion of murder in connection with Mr. Khan's tragic demise.
Det Insp Domenica Catino, representing the Metropolitan Police, noted that Mr. Khan had made a phone call at 18:55 GMT on the evening he vanished, after which he was not seen again.
While an arrest has been made, the police are urging anyone with information about the incident to come forward promptly.
The post-mortem examination conducted on Friday further confirmed the cause of Mr. Khan's death as 'extensive head injuries'.
Seyed Khan's body was discovered at Ilford Cemetery on Thursday.
The 49-year-old had last been seen at his home address in Thamesmead on 24 January, when he left to go to work at A-Z Carpets in Ilford.
His car was found in High Road.
Detectives have arrested a 30-year-old man on suspicion of murder.
Det Insp Domenica Catino, from the Metropolitan Police, said Mr Khan made a phone call at 18:55 GMT on the evening he went missing and was not seen afterwards.
"While we have made an arrest, we would encourage anyone with information about this incident to contact us immediately."
A post-mortem examination was carried out on Friday.
The New Foundation for Rural and Regional Renewal (FRRR) has recently announced the appointment of three new board members, each bringing a wealth of experience and expertise to the organization.
The new members include Andrew Johnston, Helen Middleton, and James McKenzie.
Andrew Johnston, a highly experienced finance professional, joins the board with a deep understanding of finance and investment.
His background as a trustee of John T Reid Charitable Trusts, a long-time donor partner of FRRR, positions him well to provide valuable insights and strategic guidance to the board.
Helen Middleton and her husband Michael are successful farmers based in the WA Wheatbelt region.
Managing a diversified farm growing grain, oaten hay, and pork, they have also ventured into the citrus industry with Moora Citrus, a thriving orchard near Dandaragan.
Helen's extensive agricultural knowledge and hands-on experience will be instrumental in shaping FRRR's initiatives in rural communities.
James McKenzie, residing in Sydney, brings a unique perspective to the board.

With a background in agricultural science and extensive experience in building product manufacturing and financial advisory services, James is poised to offer valuable insights into sustainable development and investment strategies for rural and regional renewal efforts.

“Andrew’s deep understanding of finance and investment, combined with his experience as a trustee of John T Reid Charitable Trusts, which has been a donor partner to FRRR over many years, will enable him to make a highly valuable contribution to the board.
Ms Middleton and her husband Michael, manage a diversified farm in the WA Wheatbelt growing grain, oaten hay and pork and have developed Moora Citrus on a 210 hectare orchard near Dandaragan.
Mr McKenzie lives in Sydney, having originally studied agricultural science at Longerenong Agricultural College in the Victorian Wimmera.
He spent 20 years working in building product manufacturing then commenced work in financial and investment advice.
Bipolar Disorder  Bipolar disorder, a mental health condition characterized by extreme mood swings, affects millions of people worldwide.
Individuals with bipolar disorder experience periods of intense emotional highs, known as mania, and lows, known as depression.
These mood swings can significantly impact a person's daily life, relationships, and overall well-being.

Living with bipolar disorder can be challenging, but with proper treatment and support, individuals can lead fulfilling lives.
Medication, therapy, and lifestyle changes are commonly used to manage symptoms and stabilize mood fluctuations.
It is essential for those with bipolar disorder to work closely with healthcare professionals to develop a personalized treatment plan that meets their unique needs.
In conclusion, raising awareness about bipolar disorder and reducing stigma surrounding mental health conditions are crucial steps towards supporting those affected by this disorder.
By fostering understanding and compassion, we can create a more inclusive and supportive environment for individuals living with bipolar disorder.

MEXICO CITY — Mexican President-elect Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador is promising that jobless youths, the elderly and Mexico’s business sector will be the biggest beneficiaries of his first year in office.
Lopez Obrador has announced a $7.5 billion investment plan aimed at supporting the country's youth and elderly population.
The funds will be allocated towards creating job opportunities for unemployed youths, providing financial assistance to the elderly, and boosting the business sector through various initiatives.
This significant financial commitment underscores Lopez Obrador's dedication to addressing key societal issues and fostering economic growth in Mexico.
By prioritizing the needs of vulnerable groups such as youths and the elderly, the incoming administration aims to create a more inclusive and prosperous society.
The investment plan is expected to have a positive impact on the country's economy and social well-being, setting a strong foundation for Lopez Obrador's presidency.

Batshuayi also scored a brace in his last Chelsea game against Newcastle on 28 January On-loan Chelsea striker Michy Batshuayi scored twice on his Borussia Dortmund debut as the German side beat Cologne.
Batshuayi, who moved to Dortmund until the end of the season on deadline day, swept home in the first half before adding a second on the hour with a clinical finish.
The Belgian striker's immediate impact delighted Dortmund fans and showcased his goal-scoring prowess.
Cologne fought back valiantly, with Simon Terodde scoring a brace to keep the game competitive until the final whistle.
However, it was Batshuayi's heroics that ultimately secured the crucial victory for Dortmund, maintaining their push for a top-four finish in the Bundesliga.
The win marked a promising start to Batshuayi's loan spell at Dortmund, leaving fans eager to see more of his goal-scoring abilities in the matches to come.
In the latest trailer for the highly-anticipated film “Venom,” fans are treated to a glimpse of Tom Hardy in his most intense role yet.
Hardy, known for his transformative performances, unleashes his inner monster as he takes on the role of Eddie Brock, a journalist who becomes the host for the alien symbiote known as Venom.
The trailer showcases the internal struggle between Brock and the symbiote as they merge to form the formidable anti-hero.
The character of Venom has a rich history in the Marvel universe, known for his dark and complex personality.
The character was also seen in 2007’s Spider-Man 3, with Brock played by former That ’70s Show star Topher Grace, to mixed reviews.
Venom, which also stars Rogue One: A Star Wars Story‘s Riz Ahmed, as well as Michelle Williams and Jenny Slate, opens October 5.
The film is set to hit theaters on October 5, promising a thrilling and action-packed experience for fans of the Marvel universe.
Get ready to witness Tom Hardy in a role like never before, as he embraces the darkness within to become Venom.
Former Israeli spy chief Tamir Pardo has revealed startling information, alleging that Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu planned a military strike on Iran back in 2011.
Pardo, who served as the head of Mossad from 2011 to 2016, claimed that Netanyahu and then-Defense Minister Ehud Barak ordered the military to prepare for an attack on Iran's nuclear facilities.
This disclosure sheds light on the behind-the-scenes tensions and strategic considerations within Israel regarding Iran's nuclear program.
The revelation by Pardo, a respected figure within the Israeli intelligence community, has sparked fresh debate over Israel's approach to Iran.
Netanyahu has long been vocal about the perceived threat posed by Iran's nuclear ambitions, advocating for a tough stance against the regime.
The Israeli leader has been a strident critic of Iran, and has accused Tehran of attempting to develop nuclear weapons.
Uruguay's prosecutor is pushing for charges to be filed against the former vice president, Raúl Sendic, over corruption allegations.
The prosecutor's move comes after a thorough investigation into Sendic's financial activities during his time in office.
The case revolves around allegations of misusing corporate credit cards for personal expenses and abusing his position for personal gain.
The corruption scandal has caused a stir in Uruguayan politics, with many calling for accountability and transparency in public office.
Sendic, who served as vice president from 2015 to 2017, has vehemently denied any wrongdoing.
However, the evidence gathered by the prosecutor paints a different picture.

The corruption allegations surfaced after a weekly publication reported that between 2010 and 2013, Sendic used corporate credit cards to make purchases at jewelry, electronics, furniture and other stores apparently unrelated to his official business.
He’s also accused of abuse of office over some contracts.
Sendic has repeatedly denied wrongdoing.
PHILADELPHIA (AP) — The fourth nor'easter in three weeks is set to smack the East Coast on the first day of spring.

The National Weather Service says the bulk of the dangerous, wind-driven snow and sleet is expected to wallop New Jersey, Maryland, Delaware and parts of eastern Pennsylvania before heading off to Nantucket early Thursday.
Residents in these areas are bracing for yet another round of winter weather, with heavy snowfall and strong winds predicted to create hazardous travel conditions and potential power outages.
Officials are urging people to stay off the roads if possible and to prepare for possible disruptions to daily routines.
Schools are already announcing closures, and transportation services are gearing up for delays and cancellations.
The unrelenting winter storms have taken a toll on the region, testing the resilience of communities already battered by the previous weather events.
Stay tuned for updates as this wintry wallop approaches.
Fox network has announced that the iconic "Showtime at the Apollo" will return as a weekly series next season.
The show, known for its electrifying performances and vibrant atmosphere, will bring the legendary Apollo Theater experience to television screens across the country on a regular basis.
Viewers can look forward to a lineup of talented performers from various genres, promising a mix of music, comedy, and entertainment.
The new series aims to capture the essence of the historic Apollo Theater, a venue that has been a launching pad for numerous music legends over the years.
Along with more guest stars, the upcoming series will feature elements from the Apollo’s legendary Amateur Night, the live talent competition now in its 82nd year.
The Apollo Theater launched the careers of legendary artists including James Brown, Stevie Wonder, Lauryn Hill and The Jackson Five.

The news comes after speculation arose during Kruger's appearance at the Cannes Film Festival earlier this month.
The Inglorious Basterds actress first fueled baby rumors during an appearance at the Cannes Film Festival earlier this month, when she wore a billowing gown that appeared to be hiding a baby bump.

Last Thursday, she further sparked speculation by sharing a black and white photo of herself on Instagram, accompanied by a footprint emoji.
Fans and well-wishers have been quick to congratulate the couple on the exciting news.
Reedus, 49, and Kruger have been in a relationship since 2016, after meeting on the set of the movie "Sky."

Both actors are known for their successful careers in the entertainment industry, with Reedus gaining fame for his role as Daryl Dixon in the hit TV series “The Walking Dead,” while Kruger has garnered acclaim for her performances in various films.
As the couple prepares to welcome their first child together, their fans eagerly anticipate more details about this new chapter in their lives.
Stay tuned for updates on this joyous occasion."
Certain to sit second in the table no matter what the result at Pride Park, Neil Warnock's side appeared on course to open a four-point cushion over Fulham when it led at the halfway stage.
Callum Paterson volleyed home at the back post to break the deadlock in the 28th minute of the rearranged fixture.
However, Cardiff collapsed after the break.

Cameron Jerome struck twice for Derby, with the striker's brace sandwiching a goal for substitute Matej Vydra, as the Rams claimed a crucial three points that lifts it above Millwall and into the final play-off berth.
The defeat was a bitter blow for Cardiff, who were aiming to secure their place in the Premier League next season.
Warnock's side will now have to regroup and refocus for their upcoming matches to ensure they maintain their position in the promotion spots.
The loss also highlighted the team's vulnerability under pressure, raising questions about their ability to handle the intensity of the promotion race.
Apostolos Vellios added a third in the 90th minute, knocking in the rebound after goalkeeper Jack Walton had kept out substitute Joe Lolley's chip.
The defeat means Barnsley remains 22nd in the table, two points behind nearest rival Bolton Wanderers with two games remaining in the season.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio (WDTN) — A car ran off the road and into a pond in Springfield on Tuesday morning.
Police responded to a call around 7:50 a.m. on Tuesday about a car in a pond in the 1500 block of Snyder Park Road.
According to police, the car is completely submerged.
Early reports indicate a woman was driving the car.
She was able to get out of the vehicle.
Eyewitnesses reported seeing the car lose control and veer off the road before plunging into the pond.
The woman managed to escape the sinking vehicle and swim to safety before emergency services arrived on the scene.
She was later treated for minor injuries at the scene by paramedics.
The Springfield Police Department is investigating the cause of the accident and is urging drivers to exercise caution on the roads, especially during inclement weather conditions.
Some types of Iogo yogurt products, distributed in all provinces except the Maritimes, are being recalled because they may contain pieces of plastic.
Raspberry, vanilla and banana drinkable yogurt and mango, strawberry-raspberry and strawberry protein based drinks are all being voluntarily recalled by Ultima Foods.
The Canadian Food Inspection Agency announced the recall June 8 and in a news release the agency said it is conducting a food safety investigation.
Consumers are advised to check their yogurt products and return them to the store or dispose of them if they have any of the affected varieties.
Ultima Foods has apologized for any inconvenience this may cause and has emphasized its commitment to food safety and quality.
Customers with any concerns or questions can contact Ultima Foods directly for more information.
Stay tuned for updates on this developing story as the investigation progresses.
Attorney General Costas Clerides made a statement today regarding the tragic murder of the Strovolos couple, expressing deep concern over the case.
Clerides emphasized the complexity of such cases and the challenges they pose to law enforcement agencies.
He assured the public that the investigation is ongoing and that every effort is being made to bring the perpetrators to justice.
Clerides acknowledged the public's demand for swift action and justice but cautioned that these investigations require meticulous attention to detail and thorough examination of evidence.
He stressed the importance of following due process to ensure a fair and just outcome for all involved parties.
“However, there is a lot of work still to be done”, Clerides said, “since cases of this kind are extremely perplexing”.
Responding to coroner’s Marios Matsakis accusations, Clerides pointed out that the state legal service is not responsible for the work carried out so far by forensic investigators.
Costas Clerides said that he is very concerned because Cyprus’ murder rate soars.

CINCINNATI — Police near Cincinnati say the mother of a 10-month-old girl sat her down in a car seat on a driveway and then apparently forgot she was there and backed a vehicle over the child, who later died.
Police say it appears to be a tragic accident that occurred midday Tuesday in Union Township, just east of Cincinnati in Clermont County.
The incident has left the community in shock and mourning for the young child's life cut short in such a heartbreaking manner.
Authorities responded swiftly to the scene, but despite their efforts, the baby succumbed to her injuries.
The mother, who has not been identified, is reportedly cooperating with the investigation.
The police are treating the incident as a terrible accident, emphasizing the need for heightened awareness and caution when children are around vehicles.
Counseling and support services are being offered to the family during this unimaginably difficult time.
The mobile gaming world today is a huge moneymaker, with in-app purchases generating way too much money in revenue.
Even popular desktop games like Fortnite and PUBG are making their way to phones to get a piece of the pie.
These types of games often have events, and the Play Store's 'My apps & games' page can now show notices for them.
The feature is pretty straightforward: it gives a short summary of the event in question in order to promote those who have it installed to hit 'Open.'
In this instance, there's some sort of summoning event for the game Fire Emblem Heroes.
The feature is definitely primarily meant for games, though other apps may also be able to take advantage of it.
This new addition to the Play Store is a significant development for app developers, providing them with a direct way to communicate with users about ongoing events and promotions within their apps.
By displaying these notices prominently on the 'My apps & games' page, developers can attract more players and increase engagement with their games.
It enhances the overall user experience by keeping players informed and involved in the latest events happening in their favorite apps.
As the mobile gaming industry continues to grow, features like these are essential for developers to stay competitive and retain a loyal user base.
Indie darlings Belle and Sebastian have sent waves of excitement through their fanbase with the announcement of the "Boaty Weekender" Cruise.
Set to take place on the high seas, the cruise promises a unique experience for music lovers and fans of the band alike.
The Scottish band revealed that the cruise will feature a lineup of top-tier musical acts handpicked by the band themselves.
In a statement, Belle and Sebastian shared their enthusiasm for the event, stating, “We are beyond thrilled to bring the Boaty Weekender to life.

It’s a dream come true for us to curate our own festival at sea and invite all of our fans to join us for this special event.”  Attendees can expect a musical extravaganza with performances from a range of artists across five stages on the ship.

Belle and Sebastian have also teased a special treat for early bookers, with the first 350 people to reserve a stateroom set to witness a unique performance of their 2000 album, "Fold Your Hands Child, You Walk Like a Peasant," in its entirety.
The news comes after a successful fan survey conducted last year, where the band sought input on potential cruise destinations and desired performers.
For fans eagerly anticipating the event, Belle and Sebastian have released an announcement video to whet their appetites.

Gigs upon gigs from some of our good friends and favourite acts in rock ‘n’ roll on five stages throughout the ship.” The news comes after last year’s survey where they hinted at the idea and had fans fill out a survey asking them who they want to see and where they would want to go.
They will also perform the entirety of their 2000 LP, Fold Your Hands Child, You Walk Like a Peasant, to the first 350 people to book a stateroom–an album never before performed in full.
Watch the announce video for the cruise below.

NEW YORK — For the fifth year in a row, Las Vegas super eater Miki Sudo took top prize at the Nathan’s Famous July Fourth hot dog eating contest, downing 37 franks and buns in 10 minutes amid stifling humidity at the annual seaside competition.
Sudo fell short of the 41 hot dogs she consumed last year but still beat out second-place finisher Mischelle Lesco of Tuscon, Arizona, who chowed down 28 wieners and buns.
On the men’s side, 10-time winner Joey “Jaws” Chestnut will confront 20 other men for the coveted Mustard Belt later Wednesday.
Sudo's victory marks her fifth consecutive win at the iconic event, solidifying her dominance in the competitive eating world.
Known for her remarkable speed and technique, Sudo's performance wowed spectators and fellow competitors alike.
Her strategic approach to consuming hot dogs, including her precise water intake and temperature preferences, has undoubtedly contributed to her consistent success on the grand stage of Coney Island.
George Shea, the longtime host of the annual Brooklyn eat-off, quipped that Sudo was particular about the temperature and amount of water she uses while competing.

Thousands of attendees, many donning mustard-colored hot dog caps, braved 83-degree temperatures and a heat index of 91 degrees to witness the annual July Fourth competition on the Coney Island boardwalk.
The outlandish tradition dates to 1972, though the company has long promoted what a former president acknowledged was a legendary start date of 1916.

Fan Martha Pleasant, 41, of Franklin, New Jersey, said she was attending the competitive eating competition to support her husband Dwight, who “loves wieners.” “We are trying to knock something off my hubby’s bucket list,” she said.
A mistaken report of a shooter prompted the lockdown of Travis Air Force Base in California on Wednesday in the midst of an emergency training exercise, officials said.
The base ordered people to shelter in place and lock their doors and windows.
Gates were closed for more than an hour before the all-clear was given at the site 45 miles northeast of San Francisco .
The incident unfolded when a training exercise involving an active shooter scenario was mistaken for a real threat.
The confusion led to a rapid response from security forces, who swiftly implemented lockdown procedures to ensure the safety of personnel on the base.
During the lockdown, law enforcement conducted a thorough sweep of the base to ensure there was no actual threat present.
Fortunately, it was determined that the initial report was a false alarm, and the situation was quickly resolved without any injuries or casualties.

Travis Air Force Base has since resumed normal operations following the security scare, with officials emphasizing the importance of remaining vigilant and prepared for emergency situations, even during training exercises.

The Country Living Fair brought the magazine’s content to life and gave guests access to a unique shopping experience, which included antiques sellers, food purveyors, artists, furniture makers, crafters and more.
Wilson County Expo Center marketing director Charity Toombs said the event brought thousands of people to the center during the three-day fair.

The fair included local Tennessee vendors, including Bradley’s Creamery, a Brentwood artisanal ice cream inspired by old-fashioned Southern favorites; Cousins Maine Lobster, a Murfreesboro food truck that serves up fresh lobster, lobster rolls, soups and sides; JBS Mercantile, a Mt.

Juliet modern farmhouse-style home décor business; Love & Fig a Nashville business with playful and fun kitchen accessories; Scarlett Scales Antiques a Franklin antiques shop; Southern Fried Design Barn a Lebanon supplier of paper goods; and more.
The fair was not just a shopping extravaganza but also a place for attendees to participate in hands-on workshops, watch demonstrations, and gain inspiration for their own homes and gardens.
Visitors were treated to live music, delicious food options, and the chance to meet the editors of Country Living Magazine.
The success of the Country Living Fair in Wilson County has set the stage for upcoming fairs in other locations.
Additional fairs are to follow in Rhinebeck, New York on June 1-3, Columbus, Ohio on June 15-17 and Sept. 14-16 and will finish up in Atlanta on Oct. 26-28.
Each fair features 200-plus vendors from more than 25 states and draws more than 25,000 visitors from across the country.

By seeking exclusive rights to this gesture, Jay-Z is looking to further solidify his brand and potentially capitalize on its popularity.

DETROIT — Jose Iglesias' two-run single keyed a Detroit's five-run sixth as the Tigers took advantage of Shohei Ohtani's departure following the second rain delay to beat the Los Angeles Angels 6-1 Wednesday night.
Ohtani, starting for the first time since May 20th, allowed one run ond three hits in five innings.
He walked three and struck out five while throwing 83 pitches.
The game was evenly poised until the sixth inning when the Tigers capitalized on the absence of Ohtani to break the deadlock.
Iglesias' timely hit was the highlight of the inning, propelling Detroit to a commanding lead.
The Tigers' offense came alive, with contributions from various players to secure the victory.
On the pitching front, Detroit's staff delivered a stellar performance, limiting the Angels to just one run throughout the game.
Matthew Boyd started on the mound for the Tigers, showcasing his skill and control to stifle the Angels' lineup.
With this win, the Tigers improved their record and demonstrated their ability to seize opportunities, especially against a tough opponent like the Angels.
The team will look to build on this momentum as they continue their season campaign.
OTTAWA — The man on trial for murdering three women in the Ottawa Valley two years ago told police he killed his three former acquaintances because they were not innocent.
Fifty-nine-year-old Basil Borutski confessed to police in an interview room at the Pembroke OPP detachment the day after the crimes in September 2015.
During the interview, Borutski claimed that the women he killed were guilty and deserved to die.
He stated that he did not consider his actions as murder because he believed the victims were responsible for their own deaths.
Borutski expressed a distorted sense of justification for his heinous acts, indicating a troubling mindset that seeks to shift blame onto the victims themselves.
The chilling revelation of Borutski's motives sheds light on the disturbing nature of the crimes committed.
The families of the victims are left grappling with the senseless loss of their loved ones, while the community at large is left reeling from the tragic events that unfolded.
As the trial progresses, more details are expected to emerge, providing further insight into the mindset of the accused and the events leading up to the brutal murders.
Four NYPD officers who responded to the Halloween terror attack on a lower Manhattan bike path were honored Monday at City Hall.

Officers Ryan Nash, Michael Welsome, Kevin McGinn and John Hasiotis received proclamations from the City Council for their work in helping to nab terror suspect Sayfullo Saipov — who is accused of using a truck to mow down at least 20 pedestrians on a bike path on Oct. 31, killing eight.
Council Speaker Melissa Mark-Viverito coincidentally presented the proclamations the same day Akayed Ullah allegedly detonated a bomb under the Port Authority Bus Terminal.
“Officers Nash, Hasiotis, Welsome and McGinn embody the tremendously selfless spirit and dedication of the NYPD,” Mark-Viverito said.
The swift and courageous actions of these officers in apprehending the suspect were commended by city officials and the community alike.

Their bravery and commitment to protecting the public in the face of danger were highlighted during the ceremony, where they were praised for their professionalism and quick response to the tragic event.
The City Council's recognition serves as a testament to the sacrifices made by law enforcement officers in ensuring the safety and security of New Yorkers.
The officers' dedication to their duty and their heroic efforts in apprehending the suspect were acknowledged as exemplary acts of service.
Carlos Gomez was craving real contact.
The star baseball player had a rough game, striking out three times in a row.
Frustrated with his performance, Gomez let his emotions get the best of him.
In a fit of anger, he smashed several water coolers in the dugout with his bat.
The loud bangs echoed through the stadium, catching the attention of fans and teammates alike.
Witnesses described Gomez as visibly upset, stomping around the dugout before unleashing his fury on the innocent water coolers.
This outburst of frustration was uncharacteristic of Gomez, known for his passion and intensity on the field.
As the incident gained attention on social media, fans speculated on the root of Gomez's frustration and what it could mean for his performance in upcoming games.
Team officials have yet to comment on the incident, leaving fans and analysts to wonder about the impact of Gomez's outburst on the team dynamics.
When golf fans look back on 2017, they’ll remark that it was Lexi Thompson’s injustice that forced one of the most important rules changes in golf’s recent history.
Thompson, a prominent figure in women’s golf, was leading the ANA Inspiration tournament when she was penalized four strokes due to a viewer calling in a rules violation that occurred a day prior.
The controversial decision not only cost Thompson the tournament but sparked a wave of criticism towards the rules and the use of viewer call-ins in golf.
Following this incident, the USGA took action to address the issue.
The USGA announced Monday it would no longer accept viewer call-ins and that it would install a panel to monitor TV coverage.
It was a smart move that was well received by the golf world — including from Lexi herself, who applauded the decision on her Twitter account.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. — A Pennsylvania man who repeatedly stabbed a woman in an Atlantic City casino parking garage last year has pleaded guilty to attempted murder.
David Legette entered his plea Tuesday as part of a deal with Atlantic County prosecutors.
The incident occurred on July 2 when Legette attacked the woman in a violent manner.
Authorities revealed that the victim had an active restraining order against Legette at the time of the attack.
Legette mercilessly stabbed the woman 19 times before locking the car doors to prevent her escape.
However, the woman displayed remarkable courage and quick thinking by reaching out of the window, unlocking the door, and rolling out of the moving vehicle as Legette drove through Ventnor.
Miraculously, she survived the harrowing ordeal, showcasing immense bravery and resilience in the face of danger.
Authorities say the victim had an active restraining order against Legette when the attack occurred July 2.
Prosecutors say Legette stabbed her 19 times, then locked the car doors so she couldn’t escape.
As Legette drove in nearby Ventnor, the woman reached out of the window and opened the door from the outside.
She then rolled herself out of the car and landed in the middle of the road as Legette drove off.
She survived the ordeal.

The Wichita Falls Police Department has seen an increase in the use of counterfeit bills.
Reports indicate a surge in fake currency circulating in various businesses across the city.

Business owners are advised to carefully inspect cash transactions, especially large denominations, using tools such as counterfeit detection pens and ultraviolet lights.
Anyone who comes across suspicious currency is encouraged to report it to the authorities immediately.

Police have arrested a woman believed to have visited neonatal units of hospitals in the Carolinas “possibly in attempts to abduct a child.” Linda Mae Everett, 36, visited a women and children’s hospital in Wilmington, NC, on April 5th, but was denied entry at a check-in desk where all visitors must present photo identification, reports the News & Observer.
Undeterred, Everett made her way to patient care areas anyway, says a rep for the New Hanover Regional Medical Center.
Authorities in South Carolina were alerted to Everett’s suspicious behavior when she was seen at the McLeod Loris Hospital in Loris.
Surveillance footage showed her wandering the halls, prompting staff to notify police.
Investigators discovered that Everett had also visited a hospital in Brunswick County, where she was seen loitering near the maternity ward.
Upon her arrest, Everett was found to have outstanding warrants in Brunswick County and was charged with trespassing in Horry County.
Police say Everett also faces one count of misdemeanor larceny tied to an incident in Brunswick County.
She is out on bond, reports WWAY.
(This woman admitted kidnapping a newborn 20 years ago.)

Cardiff City's promotion hopes took a dent on Tuesday as they let slip a lead to fall to a 3-1 defeat at the hands of Derby County.
After a goalless first half at Pride Park, Cardiff took the lead just after the break through Callum Paterson's strike in the 47th minute.
The visitors looked on course to secure a vital victory in their bid for a top-six finish.
However, Cardiff collapsed after the break.

Cameron Jerome struck twice for Derby, with the striker's brace sandwiching a goal for substitute Matej Vydra, as the Rams claimed a crucial three points that lifts them above Millwall and into the final play-off berth.
In the other Championship fixture on Tuesday, Barnsley missed the chance to move out of the relegation zone after suffering a 3-0 loss away at Nottingham Forest.
After his long-range strike curled in to put the hosts ahead at the City Ground, Lee Tomlin turned from scorer to provider to set up Ben Brereton for Forest's second before the half-time interval.
Apostolos Vellios added a third in the 90th minute, knocking in the rebound after goalkeeper Jack Walton had kept out substitute Joe Lolley's chip.
The defeat means Barnsley remain 22nd in the table, two points behind nearest rivals Bolton Wanderers with two games remaining in the season.

In a surprising move, Australia has decided to eliminate the visa program for skilled foreign workers.

The list of occupations that qualify for the new visa will be sharply reduced.

The implications of this bold move are yet to be fully understood, but it is clear that Australia is taking a new direction in its immigration policies.

Sweet news for chocoholics, Nutella have announced the launch of a new chocolate, biscuit snack bar set to launch in stores this September.
Nutella’s B-ready bar, which has all the delicious flavours of the popular hazelnut spread, will cost just 56p, and a £1.99 for a pack of six.

The Nutella B-ready bar boasts a crispy wafer shell filled with Nutella and puffed wheat crispies, making it a delightful combination of crunch and creaminess that is sure to satisfy any sweet cravings.
With its convenient packaging and affordable price point, this new snack bar is set to become a favorite among Nutella fans and snack enthusiasts alike.

Contains fewer than 120 calories Levi Boorer, customer development director at Ferrero told talkingretail.com, “Nutella B-ready is a complementary addition to the Ferrero range, offering shoppers more ‘sweet snacking’ solutions throughout the day.
“We see B-ready as the ideal mid-morning snack, containing fewer than 120 calories, while other products – like Kinder Bueno – are much more suited to post lunch snacking.
“Our initial UK trial has proved incredibly successful.
We ranged at the till in a selection of convenience stores and Nutella B-ready ranked as the fourth best performing sweet snacking line during the period.
“We also found that merchandising the single serve product separately to the multi-pack drove incremental sales.
We would recommend that the single serve features alongside popular confectionery lines like Kinder Bueno and the multipack format within the biscuits aisle.”

The Percentage of the Population that is Divorced in Each U.S. County - Gallery  A recent study delved into the percentage of the population that is divorced in each U.S. county, shedding light on the prevalence of divorce across the nation.
The data, sourced from table DP02 under Marital Status, was meticulously analyzed and visualized to provide a comprehensive overview.
It was located in table DP02 under Marital Status.
I edited out the rows I needed in Excel and then created the visualization in Tableau.
It is worth pointing out that these figures include only people that have the current marital status of “Divorced”.
Someone that was divorced and remarried or someone that was divorced, remarried, and then widowed would not be captured in these totals.
This study offers valuable insights into the demographics of divorce in different regions, highlighting variations in divorce rates among U.S. counties.
In a thrilling match against Ecuador, Alexis Sanchez emerged as the hero for Chile by scoring a late winner.
The game was evenly poised until the 87th minute when Sanchez showcased his prowess in front of goal.
Arturo Vidal capitalized on a defensive error by Ecuador and set up Felipe Gutiérrez, whose initial shot was saved.
However, Sanchez was quick to react and slammed home the rebound, securing a crucial 2-1 victory for Chile.
This vital win propels Chile to third place in the qualification table as they head into the final round of games.
With a tight race for the remaining spots, every point is crucial for Chile as they are neck-and-neck with Colombia, Peru, Argentina, and Paraguay.
The upcoming match against Brazil will be a true test of their mettle in the qualifiers.
Sanchez struck in the 87th minute to give his side a 2-1 win.
Arturo Vidal pounced on a defensive error by Ecuador and squared the ball to Felipe Gutiérrez.
His shot was saved, but Sanchez pounced on the rebound to secure three points for Chile.
The crucial win means Chile sit third in the qualification table going into the last round of games.
But they are level on points with fourth-placed Colombia, only one point ahead of Peru and Argentina, and two points ahead of Paraguay.
And Chile’s final game is against Brazil.

Recent reports have revealed a concerning trend where several high-profile companies are embroiled in scandals and unethical practices, yet their stock prices continue to soar to new heights.

The lack of accountability and oversight in the market has allowed this troubling trend to persist, with little to no consequences for those involved in illicit activities.
Experts warn that this unchecked rise in corrupt practices could have far-reaching consequences for the economy and the stability of the financial system.

A garden has been opened at Keir Hardie Primary, Newarthill, in memory of pupil Heather Hunter who died last August at the age of nine after battling heart problems for three years.
Heather’s family paid for a memorial bench at Carfin Grotto and the school wished to make its own lasting tribute.
Fundraisers were held before the summer holidays in order to facilitate landscaping an area of the playground.
The garden, dedicated to Heather, features vibrant flowers, decorative stones, and a plaque bearing her name.
It provides a peaceful space for students to reflect and remember their beloved classmate.
The school community came together to support the project, with teachers, parents, and students all contributing their time and effort to create a beautiful and meaningful memorial.
The opening ceremony was emotional yet uplifting, as friends and family gathered to honor Heather's memory and celebrate the love and compassion that she brought to their lives.
Former U.S. Navy commander, Troy Amundson, has pleaded guilty in a massive bribery case that has rocked the Navy and defense industry.

Amundson admitted to accepting bribes in the form of lavish gifts, including prostitutes and extravagant entertainment expenses, in exchange for providing privileged information to "Fat Leonard" Francis, a Malaysian businessman at the center of the scandal.
The bribes were given from 2005 to 2013, during which Amundson abused his position to help Francis overbill the Navy for various services provided to ships in Asian ports.
This revelation adds another layer to the corruption scheme that has ensnared numerous Navy officials and defense contractors.
So far, twenty individuals have confessed their involvement in the scandal, shedding light on the extent of the corruption within the Navy's ranks.
Amundson's guilty plea marks a significant development in the ongoing investigation, underscoring the far-reaching impact of this bribery scandal on the military organization.
He acknowledged that from 2005 to 2013, he accepted bribes in the form of prostitutes and entertainment expenses in exchange for helping a Malaysian businessman nicknamed "Fat Leonard" Francis.
Authorities say Francis bribed officials to help him overbill the Navy for fuel, food and other services his company provided to ships docked in Asian ports.
Twenty people have pleaded guilty so far.

Great Smoky Mountains National Park (GSMNP) has announced temporary lane closures as part of an ongoing paving project.
The park is implementing single-lane closures on Tremont Road to make up for work days lost due to inclement weather.
Visitors traveling in this area should anticipate minor delays.
However, traffic along Laurel Creek Road and Townsend Entrance Road will not be affected by the lane closures.
Travel times to Cades Cove are expected to remain normal despite the ongoing construction.
The entire paving project, covering Tremont Road, Laurel Creek Road, and Townsend Entrance Road, is scheduled to be completed by June 15, 2018.
For the latest updates on road conditions within the park, visitors are encouraged to follow SmokiesRoadsNPS on Twitter or visit the official park website at www.nps.gov/grsm.

Despite Arsenal's efforts to persuade Sanchez to stay and commit his future to the club, the player seems determined to seek a new challenge elsewhere.

With Sanchez's contract situation unresolved and his clear intention to leave, Arsenal may have to consider selling him in January to avoid losing him on a free transfer next summer.
Manchester City's interest in the player remains strong, and they could make a substantial offer to secure his services in the near future.

ISTANBUL (AP) — The head of the Turkish soccer federation says the country will bid to host the 2024 European Championship.
Federation president Yildirim Demiroren says Turkey will formally submit its bid on March 2, its fourth effort to host the European Championship.
Turkey had bid to host the final games of Euro 2020 but later withdrew its application saying it would concentrate efforts on 2024.
Demiroren expressed Turkey's readiness and determination to host the prestigious tournament, highlighting the country's passion for football and its well-equipped stadiums.
Turkey's previous bids to host major football events demonstrate its commitment to hosting international tournaments.
The European Championship would not only bring top-class football to the country but also boost tourism and the economy.
If successful, Turkey would be a vibrant and exciting host for the 2024 European Championship, providing fans with a memorable tournament experience.

Best Buy Co., the nation's largest consumer electronics retailer, says it will be handing out bonuses to more than 100,000 employees, joining a list of companies sharing a portion of their windfall from the corporate tax reform law with employees.
The one-time bonuses range from $1,000 for full-time employees to $500 for part-time workers and will be distributed based on tenure with the company.
Best Buy's move is seen as a way to acknowledge the hard work and dedication of its employees and to invest in its workforce.
This announcement comes as part of a broader trend in corporate America, where companies are using the tax savings to benefit their employees.

Best Buy joins a list of others including Walmart Inc., Walt Disney Co. and Starbucks Corp., adopting measures such as giving out bonuses, enhancing maternity benefits and raising wages in the wake of the tax overhaul.
The Best Buy bonuses were first reported by the Star Tribune in Minneapolis.
In a bizarre incident in Germany, a bird burst into flames while perched on a wire, causing a fire that quickly spread to a nearby dry field.
The burning bird fell from the wire, igniting the parched vegetation below, leading to a significant blaze in the area.
Firefighters rushed to the scene to extinguish the flames and prevent further damage to the surrounding area.
This unusual event serves as a stark reminder of the heightened fire risk posed by the current dry conditions in northeastern Germany.
The lack of rainfall in the region has created tinderbox conditions, with even a small spark posing a significant threat.
Farmers in the area have been particularly hard hit by the dry spell, struggling to keep their crops watered and facing the risk of crop failures due to the ongoing drought.
Farmers in northeastern Germany have been complaining of the effects of a persistent lack of rain over the past two months.

READING, Pa. (AP) — Albert Boscov was the public face of a department store chain he built from a single corner store in downtown Reading, Pennsylvania, to a regional powerhouse with locations in seven states and more than $1 billion in annual sales.
After his death Friday at age 87, Boscov leaves behind a chain with devoted customers and a tremendous amount of civic goodwill.
Following Albert Boscov's passing, many are left wondering about the future of Boscov's department stores.
The company, known for its commitment to local communities and personalized service, faces the challenge of maintaining its legacy without its charismatic founder at the helm.

Albert Boscov's nephew, Jim Boscov, who took over as CEO in 2015, has expressed his dedication to keeping the business within the family and preserving the values that have made Boscov's a beloved institution for decades.

Despite the inevitable changes that come with the passing of a retail titan, loyal customers and employees can take comfort in knowing that Boscov's will continue to be a family-run business, staying true to its roots and commitment to customer service.

Few department stores have been more closely identified with their owners than Boscov’s was with Albert Boscov, a cheerful executive who roamed the store aisles and was intimately familiar with his merchandise.
His nephew, who took over as CEO in 2015, says Boscov’s will remain in the family.

MILWAUKEE — Shortstop Tyler Saladino has a sprained left ankle and has been put on the 10-day disabled list by the Milwaukee Brewers, who recalled shortstop Orlando Arcia from Triple-A Colorado Springs before Wednesday’s game against the St. Louis Cardinals.

The 24-year-old Arcia has shown flashes of brilliance in the past and will look to capitalize on this second chance in the big leagues.
Saladino's injury is a setback for the Brewers, as he had been performing well both defensively and offensively.
The team hopes for a speedy recovery for Saladino while welcoming Arcia back to help fill the void in his absence.

The long-awaited breakthrough in the treatment of the most common inherited kidney disease has finally arrived with the approval of the first drug specifically designed for autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease.
Jynarque (jihn-AR’-kew), from Japan’s Otsuka Pharmaceutical, was approved Tuesday for autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease.
The progressive genetic disorder is the fourth-leading cause of kidney failure.
It causes fluid-filled cysts to develop in and damage kidneys.
The FDA rejected it in 2013 but approved it after the drugmaker did an additional study.
That one-year study, involving 1,370 patients with advanced disease, found the drug on average slowed kidney function decline about 35 per cent more than dummy pills.
Otsuka says the drug, also known as tolvaptan, will cost $13,041 per month without insurance.
Jynarque can cause serious, even fatal liver injury, excessive urination and other side effects.
—— This story has been corrected to show the drug’s price will be $13,041 per month, not $13,401.

The German government says the leaders of Germany, Russia, Ukraine and France have renewed their commitment to implementing a faltering peace deal for eastern Ukraine.

The four leaders met in Berlin to discuss the ongoing conflict in the region, emphasizing the need for all parties to fully adhere to the Minsk agreements aimed at ending the violence and restoring stability.
During the talks, they addressed issues such as the withdrawal of heavy weapons, the exchange of prisoners, and the implementation of a lasting ceasefire.

A Tennessee man managed to stop his 5-year-old son from being kidnapped — by socking the woman who was trying to swipe him in the face, cops said.
Police officials told FOX13 Memphis that the dad’s actions were deemed necessary and ultimately led him to getting his child back on Monday.
The boy’s attempted kidnapper, Gina A. Richard, 53, later said that she was under orders from “God” to try and take him.
She had tried going to a nearby fire station after getting punched and told them she was only trying to stop a kidnapping, but police later spoke with the father and confirmed what really happened.
Richard wound up getting arrested and charged with attempted aggravated kidnapping.
In her mugshot, she appears to be sporting a busted lip — courtesy of pops.
The incident has sparked a debate online, with many praising the father for his quick and decisive action in protecting his son.
Some have hailed him as a hero for his bravery and willingness to do whatever it takes to keep his child safe.
Others have criticized Richard for her bizarre claims and actions, highlighting the danger of individuals who may pose a threat to children.
“Would have done the same thing,” wrote one Facebook user.
“Wrong but right,” another said.

HONOLULU (AP) — A former congressman from Hawaii says he's leaving the Republican Party because of President Donald Trump and the failure of fellow party members to stand up to him.
Charles Djou (duh-JOO') represented Honolulu in the U.S. House from 2010 to 2011.
Djou, a moderate Republican known for his bipartisan approach, announced his decision to quit the GOP in a strongly worded statement released on Wednesday.
In his statement, Djou criticized the current direction of the party under President Trump, expressing his disappointment with the lack of accountability and integrity within the party ranks.
The former congressman highlighted Trump's divisive rhetoric and actions as a key factor in his decision to disaffiliate from the Republican Party.
Djou emphasized the importance of upholding democratic values and principles, which he believes have been compromised by the current administration.
Djou's departure from the GOP underscores the growing rift within the party as some members distance themselves from Trump's leadership.
It remains to be seen how Djou's decision will impact his political future and whether other Republicans will follow suit in denouncing the party's alignment with the president.>
In a bid to enhance durability and performance, a new equalizing beam with bushing has been introduced by a leading automotive manufacturer.
The rotating bar pin bushing uses the same rubber and bonding as the standard end bushing, and the rotating bar pin will lock into place once under load.
It all helps to eliminate the inner bushing wear, the company says.
The equalizing beam itself is made of a high-strength steel, and is identical to the one used in production, complete with the robotic welds.
Complete with robotic welds, this new component promises to provide reliable support and stability to the vehicle's suspension system.

Nordic Aquafarms sees Maine's mid-coast region as a prime location to establish a major salmon farming operation, capitalizing on the region's pristine waters and supportive regulatory environment.

Paul LePage says he's supporting the project, which he says will grow the economy and seafood industry in the state's mid-coast region.

Nordic Aquafarms chief executive officer Erik Heim says Maine is the best location for the firm to expand in the U.S. Maine and New Brunswick, Canada, are home to longstanding salmon farming operations.

In a tragic incident in Saboba, two individuals lost their lives in a devastating fire that broke out on Tuesday evening.
The victims, identified as a middle-aged couple, were unable to escape the blaze that engulfed their home in the small community.
According to eyewitnesses, the fire started suddenly and spread rapidly, leaving little time for the couple to react.
Local residents attempted to extinguish the flames using whatever means available, but their efforts were in vain as the fire quickly consumed the entire structure.
Emergency services were called to the scene, but by the time they arrived, it was too late to save the lives of the couple.

India's government is set to engage in crucial discussions with primary dealers ahead of what is anticipated to be near-record bond sales.
With a focus on managing the country's debt amid challenging economic conditions, the upcoming meetings aim to strategize the best approach for the significant issuance of bonds.
The decision to convene with primary dealers underscores the government's commitment to navigating the current financial landscape effectively.

By seeking input and collaboration from key stakeholders in the financial market, India aims to ensure the successful execution of its upcoming bond sales while also maintaining stability in the market.
The timing of these discussions is particularly critical as India grapples with a series of challenges impacting its bond market.
India’s bonds have slumped for seven straight months, the longest stretch in two decades.
A rising debt supply, climbing global yields, faster inflation and the prospect of higher interest rates have all helped sour sentiment.
In a recent development, a court has dismissed a lawsuit filed against Twitter over a terror attack.
The lawsuit was brought forth by the families of Lloyd Fields and James Creach, who tragically lost their lives in a 2015 attack in Jordan.
The families contended that Twitter's platform played a significant role in the attack, as IS-affiliated accounts were allegedly used to coordinate and promote extremist activities.
However, the court ruled in favor of Twitter, stating that the company could not be held accountable for the actions of individual users on its platform.
The decision highlights the challenges in holding social media companies liable for content shared by their users, especially in cases involving terrorism and violence.
Despite the setback, the families' attorney, Joshua Arisohn, mentioned that they are considering appeals to seek further justice in this matter.
Lloyd Fields and James Creach were shot and killed in Jordan in 2015 by a Jordanian police captain while training law enforcement officers.
Their families argued that IS Twitter accounts were a substantial factor in the men's deaths and that the company should have anticipated attacks.
Joshua Arisohn, an attorney for the families, says appeals are being considered.
YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio (AP) – A state prison will use equipment seized from an illegal marijuana grower to cultivate vegetables for poor people.

The Vindicator of Youngstown, Ohio, reports tens of thousands of dollars’ worth of hydroponic equipment seized by police in Campbell has been donated to the Trumbull Correctional Institution for the prison’s inmate agricultural program.
Inmates at the maximum security prison in northeast Ohio grew 10,000 pounds of food donated to poor people last year.
The initiative aims to not only provide fresh produce to those in need but also to offer inmates a chance to contribute positively to society.
By repurposing confiscated equipment for a noble cause, the prison hopes to instill a sense of purpose and responsibility in the inmates.
The collaboration between law enforcement, the prison, and the community demonstrates a creative and impactful approach to addressing societal challenges.
Campbell Mayor Nick Phillips says equipment found during raids is usually destroyed but was instead donated after a prison official asked for it.
Phillips says “it’s nice to see good coming from bad.”

On the fateful night of the 2016 presidential election, tension and disappointment filled the air as Hillary Clinton made a heartfelt and unexpected apology to President Barack Obama.
Sources close to the former Secretary of State revealed that Clinton reached out to Obama to express her regrets for the outcome of the election.
The conversation between the two political heavyweights was described as emotional and reflective, with Clinton acknowledging the defeat and its implications for the country.
The apology came as a surprise to many, considering the high stakes and intense rivalry between Clinton and Obama during the Democratic primary race in 2008.
However, in a moment of humility and grace, Clinton set aside any past grievances to offer a sincere apology to the President.
Despite the disappointment of the election results, Obama reportedly urged Clinton to concede graciously and put the country's interests first.
“You need to concede,” Obama told Clinton directly, later repeating the instruction to her campaign chairman John Podesta for good measure.
The directive came after Clinton ignored previous messages from White House staff to throw in the towel.
She conceded the loss publicly the next morning.

Russian legislator Anton Morozov of the nationalist Liberal-Democratic Party has raised concerns about North Korea's missile capabilities, stating that North Korean missiles may have the ability to reach the US.

Anton Morozov of the nationalist Liberal-Democratic Party said in remarks carried by Russian state news agency RIA Novosti on Friday that North Korea is preparing to test-fire a long-range missile "in the nearest future."

Morozov, who visited North Korea with two fellow lawmakers earlier this week, said that their interlocutors told them that Pyongyang has the technology that would allow missile warheads to survive the heat while entering the atmosphere.
He said North Koreans also showed them "mathematical calculations which they say prove that their missile is capable of reaching the U.S. West Coast."
The revelation adds to the growing global concerns surrounding North Korea's missile program and its potential threat to international security.

Most people subscribe to Netflix to binge-watch “Stranger Things.” But one person in the U.K. used it to watch “Bee Movie” every day.

Sinclair Broadcast Group has announced the sale of nine of its TV stations for a total of $441.7 million.
The move comes as part of the company's efforts to streamline its operations and focus on core business areas.
The sale includes stations in various states, such as Oklahoma, Michigan, North Carolina, Virginia, and Iowa, as well as four stations in Pennsylvania.
Sinclair, one of the largest television station operators in the United States, currently owns a total of 193 stations nationwide.
The decision to sell these stations is seen as a strategic move by Sinclair to optimize its portfolio and allocate resources more efficiently.
The sale is expected to have a positive impact on the company's financial position and future growth prospects.
At the time, President Donald Trump tweeted his support of the network.
The stations include one each in Oklahoma, Michigan, North Carolina, Virginia and Iowa and four in Pennsylvania.

LOS ANGELES (AP) — Walker Buehler, the Dodgers' prized pitching prospect, has been optioned to Single-A Rancho Cucamonga, although the right-hander could be back in the majors this weekend.
Buehler made his first big league start on Monday night against Miami.
The 23-year-old allowed four hits over five scoreless innings and struck out five, but didn't factor in the decision in the Dodgers' 2-1 win.
Manager Dave Roberts said the team wanted to keep Buehler in the same time zone and nearby so it would have the option of starting him on Saturday at San Francisco.
The decision to send Buehler to Single-A is seen as a strategic move by the Dodgers to manage the young pitcher's workload and development carefully.
Buehler has shown immense potential, and the organization is keen on nurturing his talent for long-term success in the major leagues.
Although Buehler may be disappointed by the demotion, it is viewed as a temporary setback in his promising career.
Fans and analysts alike are eagerly anticipating his return to the big leagues, where he has the opportunity to showcase his skills and contribute significantly to the Dodgers' pitching rotation.

Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email A woman was taken to hospital after being cut out of a car following a crash in Reading on Monday, January 2.
Firefighters cut the woman out of a silver Vauxhall Corsa after it was involved in a collision with a taxi in Chatham Street at around 12.08pm.
A South Central Ambulance spokeswoman said the woman was trapped in the car and had to be freed by firefighters.
She added: "The woman, in her 40s, suffered minor head, chest and back injuries.
"She was treated at the scene and then taken to the Royal Berkshire Hospital."
The crash resulted in Chatham Street being closed for several hours as emergency services worked to clear the scene and investigate the cause of the accident.
The incident caused significant traffic disruptions in the area, with diversions put in place to redirect vehicles away from the scene.
Witnesses reported seeing a large emergency service presence at the site of the crash, with police officers, firefighters, and paramedics all in attendance.
The collision left both vehicles significantly damaged, with debris scattered across the road.
(Photo: Get Reading) The road reopened around 2pm once both vehicles had been recovered.
Police are appealing for witnesses, anyone with information should call the non emergency number on 101 and quote the URN 378 2/1.
Or call Crimestoppers anonymously on 0800 555 111.
Two-time world champion ski racer Erik Guay of Canada says he will not be able to compete at the Pyeongchang Olympics because of a back injury.
Guay announced Wednesday on social media that he'll sit out the Winter Games, which open next week in South Korea.
The 36-year-old from Quebec has been struggling with back pain for several months and has decided to prioritize his health over competing in the Olympics.
Guay might have been one of Canada's leading medal hopes among the men in Alpine skiing.
He won gold medals at the world championships in downhill in 2011 and in super-G last year, when he also took home a silver in the downhill.
Guay also has 24 top-three finishes in World Cup races.

The Philippine government remains steadfast in its commitment to uphold the 'no ransom policy' despite the recent threat from the Abu Sayyaf group to kill German hostage Jurgen Kantner.
The extremist group had set a deadline for a ransom payment and threatened to execute Kantner if their demands were not met.

Presidential spokesperson Ernesto Abella reiterated the government's stance against paying ransom to terrorist groups, emphasizing that giving in to their demands would only fund their criminal activities and put more lives at risk.
Abella assured the public that all possible measures are being taken to ensure Kantner's safe release without caving in to the terrorists' demands.
Security forces have been mobilized in the area where Kantner is being held captive, with efforts focused on securing his safe release through non-negotiated means.
The government is working tirelessly to coordinate a swift and strategic response to the threat posed by the Abu Sayyaf group, prioritizing the safety and well-being of the hostage.
“The government will continue efforts to safely rescue all hostages held by these terrorists.
It is also working closely with the concerned local governments as well as other sectors to facilitate the safe rescue of Mr. Jurgen Kantner,” Abella said.
For his part, Peace Adviser Jesus Dureza on Tuesday vowed: “I will never stop appealing to the captors to spare the lives of those innocent victims for the sake of their families and loved ones.”

Every year on Easter Monday, various unique and quirky traditions are celebrated around the world.
One such tradition is the Hare Pie Scramble in the village of Hallaton, England.
Dating back centuries, this event involves the townspeople dividing into two teams, the Bottles and the Hares, to compete for a hare pie.
The pie is then cut into pieces and thrown into the crowd, sparking a lively scramble to secure a portion believed to bring good luck.
In Corfu, Greece, the celebration involves a tradition called "Pot Throwing."
Residents throw pots, pans, and other earthenware out of their windows to symbolize the arrival of spring and the new crops that will be harvested.
This unique custom is said to ward off evil spirits and bring good fortune for the coming year.
Meanwhile, in the Czech Republic, women are playfully spanked with a decorated willow whip called a "pomlázka" to ensure health and fertility.
This tradition, known as "Easter spanking," is believed to bring vitality and youthfulness to those who receive the gentle taps.
These diverse and colorful Easter Monday traditions showcase the rich tapestry of cultures and customs around the world, each with its own special significance and charm.
The World Coal Carrying Championships, Gawthorpe, England.
Since 1963, participants have raced about two-thirds of a mile carrying a sack of coal — 110 pounds for men, 44 pounds for women.
In the United States, children gather on the lawn outside the president’s house and use spoons to roll wooden eggs along a race course.
They can also make crafts with the president’s family and listen to books being read by members of his administration.
LEXINGTON, S.C. — A Baptist church’s congregation has voted to remove a statue of Jesus Christ because some believe it’s too “Catholic” for their place of worship.
The decision made by the congregation of the Red Bank Baptist Church has stirred controversy and debate within the community.
The life-size statue, depicting Jesus with his arms outstretched, has been a focal point in the church for years but has now become a point of contention.
The pastor of the church sent a letter to the artist who created the statue, explaining the reasons behind the removal.

The letter says some in the congregation believe the image of Christ standing with his arms outstretched is “Catholic in nature.” The artist responded that the pastor’s letter displays religious prejudice and insults the community’s intelligence.
Photo/Facebook A Nanaimo medical marijuana dispensary that opened near a daycare has been shut down by police.
Nanaimo RCMP descended on Leaf Labs at 679 Terminal Avenue on Monday.
The dispensary, which had been operating for several months, raised concerns among local residents due to its proximity to the daycare facility.
Following a thorough investigation, police obtained a search warrant and conducted a raid on the premises.
Authorities arrested the owner of the dispensary on charges related to the illegal distribution of marijuana.
The business was then closed and secured.
Officers later seized approximately 1.5 pounds of marijuana during a search of the premises.
“The RCMP is guided by the existing laws and legislation.

We recognize the current complexities surrounding the potential for future legislative changes, however, the RCMP is mandated with enforcing the laws of Canada as they exist today,” says Superintendent Cameron Miller, Officer in Charge of the Nanaimo RCMP.
The man arrested was released with a promise to appear in court in July.
Apple has announced its plans to address the ongoing investigations by the US government regarding the intentional slowdown of older iPhone models.
The tech giant's response comes after facing scrutiny for slowing down iPhones through software updates without clear disclosure to users.

A software update released in 2016 began to slow down older iPhones when their batteries weakened to prevent them from abruptly turning off, but Apple didn't fully disclose what it was doing until December.
Apple has since apologized for not being more forthcoming and is replacing batteries on older iPhones for $29, a $50 discount.

Robert Lewandowski scored a hat trick on Thursday night as Poland routed Armenia 6-1 to move to the the brink of qualification for the 2018 World Cup in Russia.
The 29-year-old Bayern Munich star started the game with 47 international goals, one behind the record of 48 held since 1980 by Wlodzimierz Lubanski.
Lewandowski wasted no time in making history, scoring a quick brace in the first 14 minutes of the match to equal and then surpass Lubanski's long-standing record.
His third goal came in the second half, solidifying his place as Poland's all-time leading goal scorer.
The striker's clinical finishing and remarkable consistency have made him a standout player for both club and country.
In addition to Lewandowski's heroics, Poland's victory over Armenia showcased their attacking prowess and solidified their position as a strong contender in international football.
With the win, Poland now sits comfortably atop their World Cup qualifying group, poised to secure a spot in the tournament next summer.
Lewandowski's record-breaking performance will undoubtedly be remembered as a historic moment in Polish football history.
White House Press Secretary, Sarah Huckabee Sanders, confirmed today that President Trump is not currently taking action to fire Special Counsel Robert Mueller.
Sanders addressed the recent tweets by the President expressing his frustration with the ongoing investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 election.
"The president is not moving to get rid of Robert Mueller," he said.
He said the tweets reflected "some well-established frustration" felt by Trump over the Russian investigation.
Despite the President's public statements, Sanders reiterated that there are no immediate plans to dismiss Mueller.
The White House's stance on the matter comes amidst growing speculation and concerns regarding the future of the special counsel's investigation.
Mueller's team continues its work, focusing on potential collusion between the Trump campaign and Russia, as well as obstruction of justice allegations.

In a heartwarming display of compassion and dedication, a team of wildlife rehabilitators is working tirelessly to nurse a group of displaced baby Least Terns back to health after they were affected by severe weather conditions.
The young birds, who were left vulnerable and in need of care due to the adverse weather, are being given round-the-clock attention and support at a local wildlife rehabilitation center.
The baby Least Terns, known for their distinctive appearance and endangered status, were found struggling to survive after being displaced from their natural habitat by the recent bad weather.
The team of experts caring for them is providing specialized care and creating a nurturing environment to help them recover and thrive.
These efforts to rehabilitate the displaced baby Least Terns highlight the importance of conservation and wildlife protection, especially for vulnerable species like the Least Terns.

THE HAGUE, Netherlands (AP) — The Netherlands' main intelligence service says it is treating a small group of Dutch children in conflict zones in Iraq and Syria as "Jihadist travelers" since they may have received military training.

The Dutch General Intelligence and Security Service, known by its Dutch acronym AIVD, reported that these children, mostly under the age of 9, have been exposed to radical ideologies and potential combat experience.
Concerns are rising over the potential threat these children could pose if they return to the Netherlands, possibly indoctrinated and desensitized to violence.
It says fewer than 20 percent of the children are age 9 or older.

The report says that because children in territory controlled by the so-called Islamic State group "sometimes receive weapons and combat training from as young as nine years old," intelligence officials consider them jihadi travelers.
Dutch authorities routinely detain people caught returning from Syria if they are suspected of extremist links.

WARSAW, Poland (AP) — Poland's Senate has backed legislation regulating Holocaust speech that has sparked a diplomatic dispute with Israel and calls from the United States for a reconsideration of a bill seen as threatening freedom of speech.

The bill proposed by Poland's ruling conservative party calls for up to three years in prison for any intentional attempt to falsely attribute the crimes of Nazi Germany to the Polish state or people.
It exempts artistic and research work.
The controversial law has drawn criticism from various quarters, with opponents arguing that it could stifle open discussion and historical research on Poland's role during World War II.
Israel has strongly condemned the legislation, warning that it could lead to the distortion of historical truth and the silencing of survivors' testimonies.
The United States has also expressed concerns, urging Poland to reconsider the potential impact on freedom of speech and academic inquiry.
The bill will now go to the president for final approval.

More people are on pace to die this year from drug overdoses in Hancock County compared to last year.
According to recent data, the county is on track to surpass the overdose numbers recorded in 2016.
Local authorities are working tirelessly to combat this troubling trend, implementing various programs and initiatives to address substance abuse issues within the community.
The rise in overdose cases has sparked concern among residents and officials, prompting a collective effort to increase awareness and provide support for those struggling with addiction.
Efforts are being made to enhance access to treatment and recovery resources, as well as to educate the public on the dangers of drug abuse.
Community organizations and healthcare providers are collaborating to offer assistance and guidance to individuals affected by substance use disorders.
By coming together and taking proactive measures, Hancock County aims to reverse the current trajectory and save lives from the devastating impact of drug overdoses.

A woman is facing battery charges after allegedly kicking a disabled patient multiple times.
Attorney General Jeff Landry reported Flora Williams, 53, of Baton Rouge, is accused of committing battery against her Medicaid patient.
The incident reportedly took place at a care facility where Williams worked as a caregiver.
According to officials, Williams was caught on camera kicking the patient, who has a disability, in the leg and abdomen.
The victim, who is unable to speak, was visibly in pain during the incident.
Williams has since been arrested and charged with battery of a vulnerable person.
The Attorney General's office is working closely with the facility to ensure the safety and well-being of all patients under their care.

WARSAW, Poland (AP) — Polish President Andrzej Duda has signed into law a bill that largely limits trade on Sundays, saying it will benefit family life.
The new law restricts Sunday shopping to the first and last Sunday of each month, with some exceptions around holiday periods.
Supporters of the legislation argue that by giving workers more time off, families will have the opportunity to spend quality time together and strengthen their bonds.

The move has been met with mixed reactions, with some praising the focus on family well-being and the chance for workers to have a day of rest, while others express concerns about the impact on businesses and consumer choice.
The law is part of a broader effort to promote a healthier work-life balance and prioritize family values in Polish society.

The Gloucester center has been rewarded for his impressive performances in recent matches, earning the trust of the coaching staff.
Harris will line up alongside experienced players like Stuart Hogg and Finn Russell, bringing his defensive prowess and attacking flair to the team.

The colorful 12-foot tall peacock sculpture, created by local artist Sarah Miller, is a must-see attraction at this year's event.

The incident occurred when the Israeli, whose identity has not been disclosed, entered the village by mistake and was met with hostility from local residents.
According to initial reports, the individual was physically assaulted before managing to escape the area and seek help.
