A new prison unit designed specifically for young inmates is gaining national attention as a potential model for rehabilitation.
It houses 18- to 25-year-old inmates along with older mentors, some of whom are serving life sentences.
The unit is based on a prison in Germany and focuses on education, family and skill development.
This innovative approach aims to provide young offenders with guidance and support to help them turn their lives around.
By pairing them with older inmates who act as mentors, the unit creates a supportive environment where individuals can learn from each other and build positive relationships.
The focus on education and skill development provides inmates with the tools they need to reintegrate into society successfully.
This model is being closely watched by experts and policymakers as a potential solution to the challenges of youth incarceration.
Nokia has announced it will re-launch the world’s most loved mobile phone - the Nokia 3310!
The Nokia 3310 was first launched in 2000 and some people are still using them.
To date, 126 millions Nokia 3310 phones have been sold.
The 3310 won cult status because of its near indestructible durability.
It also featured much loved games such as ‘Snake II’ and ‘Space Impact’.
The new incarnation of the phone will be sold for just €59 and will be launched at the Mobile World Congress later this month.
Fans of the classic device are thrilled about the re-launch, with many nostalgic for the simpler times when mobile phones were primarily used for calling and texting.
The new version is expected to retain the iconic design elements while incorporating modern technology updates to meet current market demands.
The affordable price point makes it an attractive option for those seeking a reliable and straightforward mobile phone experience.
Stay tuned for more updates on the Nokia 3310 re-launch at the Mobile World Congress!
An independent probe has been launched into the death of a man who was arrested in Surrey, B.C.
The incident occurred when Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP) officers attempted to speak to the man, leading to his arrest.
During the arrest, the man reportedly experienced medical distress, prompting officers to call for paramedic assistance.
Despite the efforts of paramedics, the man tragically passed away shortly after being taken into custody.
The RCMP has stated that the Independent Investigation Office, which handles all cases involving police-related deaths or serious injuries, has taken charge of the investigation.
They are actively seeking witnesses to provide any information that may shed light on the circumstances leading to the man's death.
Additionally, the coroner's service has been informed and will be involved in determining the cause of death.
Mounties say officers tried to speak to the man and, when he was taken into custody, he went into medical distress.
Despite help from paramedics, police say the man died soon after.
The Independent Investigation Office, the organization that probes all police-involved cases of death or serious injury, has taken over the case and is looking to speak with witnesses.
The coroner’s service has also been notified.
CONCORD, N.H. (AP) — New Hampshire's highest court will begin hearing the case of three women who are challenging a city ordinance that barred them from going topless at a beach.
The women, represented by the Free the Nipple movement, argue that the ordinance violates their constitutional rights to freedom of expression and is discriminatory.
The controversy began when the women were fined for going topless at a local beach, prompting them to file a lawsuit against the city.
They argue that there is no explicit state law prohibiting female toplessness and that the ordinance unfairly targets women.
The women appealed to the state Supreme Court after a district court judge rejected their request to dismiss the case.
Oral arguments are scheduled for Thursday.
The women say there's no state law forbidding female toplessness and call the case gender-based discrimination because men don't have to cover their nipples.
Town ordinance supporters say it's for the protection of children and families.
DAYTONA BEACH, Fla. — Police in Florida say two visiting New York first responders helped save a 3-year-old girl who was drowning in a hotel swimming pool.

WFTV in Orlando reports that New York State Trooper Matthew Colwell and Jessica Campeta, a firefighter from Hudson, New York, pulled the child from the deep end of the pool at the La Quinta Inn in Daytona Beach on Tuesday evening.
The incident unfolded when Colwell and Campeta noticed the young girl struggling in the water and immediately sprang into action.
With their quick thinking and training, they were able to swiftly rescue the child from the dangerous situation.
The girl was reportedly unconscious when she was pulled from the pool but was revived by the responders who administered CPR until paramedics arrived.
Authorities praised the heroic actions of Colwell and Campeta, highlighting the importance of their swift response in saving the young girl's life.
The child was later transported to the hospital for further evaluation and is expected to make a full recovery.
Under Armour's CEO Kevin Plank has decided to step down from President Donald Trump's Manufacturing Council.
Plank is the founder, CEO, and chairman of Under Armour.
He announced his decision to step down from the council in a statement, saying that his company “engages in innovation and sports, not politics.”
Plank's departure follows other high-profile executives who have also left the council in recent days.
This move comes amidst growing criticism of President Trump's response to the recent violence in Charlottesville, Virginia.
Plank's decision reflects a trend of business leaders distancing themselves from the current administration.
As Under Armour continues to navigate its position in the current political climate, Plank's departure signals a shift in the relationship between corporate leaders and the White House.

Jim Impoco, who had shepherded Newsweek through most of the turmoil that rocked parent company IBT Media last summer, was himself given the old heave-ho as editor-in-chief of the weekly on Tuesday after 3 ¹/₂ years at the title.
Matt McAllester, who had been editing the international edition out of London, will run both editions.
The sudden departure of Impoco came as a surprise to many within the organization.
Under his leadership, Newsweek had weathered significant challenges, including financial difficulties and a shrinking staff.
Impoco was known for his strong editorial direction and commitment to investigative journalism, which had garnered both praise and criticism during his tenure.
Matt McAllester, the newly appointed editor-in-chief, brings a wealth of experience to the role.
Having worked on the international edition, McAllester is well-versed in the global landscape of news and has a proven track record of delivering impactful stories to readers worldwide.
His leadership is expected to bring a fresh perspective to Newsweek and drive the publication forward in an ever-changing media landscape.
The switch at the top, first reported by Politico, was engineered by the new IBT CEO Dev Pragad.
He had arrived from Britain as CEO last fall and had previously worked with McAllester, who shared a Pulitzer Prize earlier in his career at Newsday.

Pragad did not return a call seeking comment — but in his Tuesday memo said, “Matt and I share the same vision for Newsweek, one that expands our reach and influence and grows our audience across the globe, and will enable us to build upon an already excellent editorial team in both the US and the UK.” Of course insiders worry that with Impoco gone, more cuts are on the way.
HARRISONVILLE, Mo.
(AP) — A man connected to two Kansas City-area women who disappeared about 10 years apart has been charged with murder in their deaths.
Kylr Yust, 32, faces two counts of first-degree murder and two counts of abandonment of a corpse in the deaths of Kara Kopetsky and Jessica Runions.
Kopetsky, 17, went missing in May 2007, while Runions, 21, disappeared in September 2016.
Yust was previously questioned in the cases but had not been charged until now.
The families of both women have long suspected Yust's involvement in their disappearances and have been seeking justice for years.
Kopetsky had filed a protection order against Yust in April 2007, a month before she went missing after walking out of Belton High School.
The remains of Kopetsky and Runions were found in April in a rural area near Belton.
In a surprising turn of events, Superintendent John Largent has announced his decision to run against incumbent State Representative Sarah Lang in the upcoming primary election.
Largent, known for his dedication to education and community development, believes that it is time for a change in leadership at the state level.

Largent's decision to enter the political arena has sparked excitement and curiosity among local residents who are eager to see how his experience as a superintendent will translate into a political campaign.
With a strong track record of advocating for students and families, Largent is positioning himself as a candidate who will prioritize the needs of the community above all else.
Lang, who is seeking a second term, is expected to face a tough challenge from Largent in the Republican primary.
The election is set for March 6, and both candidates are gearing up for what promises to be a competitive race.
Largent has affirmed that he will continue serving as superintendent during the campaign and has pledged to retire if elected.
Lang is seeking a second term.
“I am very concerned that too many politicians today are taking marching orders from powerful special interests and no longer represent the people who elected them,” Largent said.

“When politicians care more about pleasing a handful of wealthy elites than standing up for their districts, communities like ours lose our representation.” Largent, 52, will run against Lang in the March 6 Republican primary.
Largent said he will remain superintendent during the campaign and will retire if elected.

SEOUL, South Korea (AP) — North Korea says it released an American university student over what it calls humanitarian reasons in its first official comment since he was returned to his home state of Ohio in a coma.
The state-run Korean Central News Agency on Thursday said Otto Warmbier had been sentenced to hard labor but didn't comment on his medical condition.
Warmbier, a student at the University of Virginia, was detained in January 2016 for alleged anti-state activities while visiting North Korea as a tourist.
His release came after intense diplomatic efforts by the U.S. government.
Warmbier's family announced his death shortly after his return, with doctors in the U.S. stating he had suffered severe brain damage.
The circumstances surrounding his detention and subsequent condition have raised international concerns and condemnation.
North Korea's decision to release him on humanitarian grounds is seen as a rare move by the isolated nation.
NASA is set to make history by providing the first-ever live 360-degree view of a rocket launch.
Viewers around the world will have the opportunity to experience the excitement and thrill of a rocket launch like never before.
This groundbreaking initiative aims to offer a unique perspective on the event, allowing viewers to feel as though they are right there at the launch site.
The live 360-degree view will be made possible by multiple cameras strategically placed around the launch pad, capturing every angle of the rocket as it takes off into space.
A computer in a blast-proof box will stitch together the images for a full, in-the-round view.
There will be about a minute lag time.
It will be shown on NASA's YouTube channel .

You must enter the characters with black color that stand out from the other characters Message: * A friend wanted you to see this item from WRAL.com: http://wr.al/18pPc — A group of protesters in Durham toppled a Confederate monument Monday evening.
The statue is called the Confederate Soldiers Monument and was dedicated in 1924.
The protest began at about 6 p.m. near the old courthouse and a portion of East Main Street was closed as a result.
Several men used a ladder to reach the top of statue, which had been sprayed with cooking spray by authorities to make it more difficult to climb, and it was pulled down with a rope.
Protesters began kicking the statue and chanting after it fell.
They then began marching to the police department, blocking a number of downtown streets in the process.
The protest dispersed just before 8 p.m.
The toppling of the Confederate monument comes amidst ongoing national debates surrounding the removal of Confederate symbols and statues.
Supporters of the removal argue that these monuments represent a painful history of racism and oppression, while opponents view them as important historical markers.
The incident has sparked mixed reactions within the community, with some residents applauding the protesters for taking action, while others condemn the destruction of public property.
Authorities are investigating the incident and are urging for calm and peaceful demonstrations in the future.
The event serves as a reminder of the deep-rooted tensions surrounding symbols of the Confederate era and the ongoing struggle for racial equality and justice in America.

BARCELONA, Spain (AP) — David Goffin saved a match point to defeat Marcel Granollers of Spain 4-6, 7-6 (2), 6-2 Tuesday in the second round of the Barcelona Open.
Goffin was down 5-1 in the second set before recovering to reach the third round for the second consecutive year in Barcelona.
The match was a thrilling display of resilience from Goffin, who found himself on the brink of elimination before mounting a remarkable comeback.
Despite dropping the first set, the Belgian remained composed and fought back fiercely in the second set tiebreak, showcasing his mental fortitude under pressure.
Granollers, supported by the home crowd, put up a valiant effort and even held a match point in the second set.
However, Goffin refused to back down and raised his level of play when it mattered most, eventually sealing the victory after a grueling battle that lasted over two hours.
With this hard-fought win, Goffin advances to the next round where he will face a formidable opponent as he continues his quest for success in the Barcelona Open.

Myisha McFarland and her daughter Cierra were last seen in a southern area of Kansas City in a dark blue Mazda 6, with Missouri License AK0-G7N.

LONDON (AP) — Prince Charles says it is a "great joy" to be a grandfather once again, issuing a statement to express his pleasure with the arrival of a boy to the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge.
The royal family welcomed the newest member, born at a London hospital, with great excitement and anticipation.
The baby, whose name has not been revealed yet, is the couple's third child and fifth in line to the throne.
Prince Charles, who is already a doting grandfather to Prince George and Princess Charlotte, expressed his happiness at the news and conveyed his best wishes to the new parents.
The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge are said to be overjoyed with the new addition to their family, and royal well-wishers from around the world have been sending their congratulations.
The birth of the royal baby has sparked celebrations across the United Kingdom, with the public eagerly awaiting a glimpse of the newest member of the royal family.

RICHMOND, Va. — A federal appeals court has scheduled arguments for Dec. 5 in the case of a former Russian military officer sentenced to life in prison for leading a 2009 Taliban attack on U.S. forces in Afghanistan.
Lawyers for Irek Hamidullin have argued that he shouldn’t have faced trial because he is a lawful combatant.
Hamidullin was convicted in 2015 on charges including providing material support to terrorism and conspiring to use a weapon of mass destruction.
His legal team contends that he was a legitimate prisoner of war at the time of the attack.
The upcoming arguments will focus on whether Hamidullin should have been classified as a lawful combatant under the international laws of warfare.
The case has drawn attention for its implications on the treatment of captured combatants in conflicts involving non-state actors.
The outcome of the upcoming court session could have far-reaching consequences for future cases involving similar circumstances.
by Jacque English The Five Rivers Bee Club, FRBC, meets the second Tuesday of every month at 6:30 p.m. at Grandma’s Country Cookin’ in Hardy.
John Goodson, Sharp County Board of Health Food Inspector, will be the guest speaker at their Tuesday, December 12 meeting.
Goodson will discuss selling honey as a hobbyist beekeeper.

They are a small non-profit club for hobbyists, backyard honeybee beekeepers, and wish to extend an invitation to come to our meetings to learn more about Honeybees and how we can help to increase their dwindled numbers.
The FRBC is dedicated to educating its members about the importance of bees in our ecosystem and the art of beekeeping.
With bee populations facing challenges like habitat loss, pesticide use, and disease, the club aims to raise awareness and promote sustainable beekeeping practices.
The upcoming meeting promises to be informative and engaging for both seasoned beekeepers and those new to the hobby.
Attendees will have the opportunity to network with fellow bee enthusiasts, learn from experienced speakers like Goodson, and exchange tips and tricks for successful beekeeping.
Whether you are a seasoned beekeeper or just curious about bees, the Five Rivers Bee Club welcomes all who share a passion for these vital pollinators.
Join us on December 12 to learn more about beekeeping and how you can contribute to the preservation of honeybee populations.

Europe’s two largest supermarkets, French giant Carrefour and Tesco, will form a worldwide alliance despite warnings from the remain campaign that Brexit would isolate British retail and hit consumers’ wallets.
Tesco announced the strategic partnership with Carrefour, aiming to leverage their combined buying power to negotiate better deals with suppliers and offer lower prices to customers.
This cross-channel alliance is seen as a bold move by Tesco to secure its position in the market post-Brexit and navigate potential disruptions in the supply chain.

The partnership between Tesco and Carrefour is expected to create a stronger competitive edge in the retail industry, enabling both companies to expand their product offerings and enhance their market presence.
Despite the uncertainties surrounding Brexit, Tesco’s decision to collaborate with Carrefour demonstrates a commitment to delivering value and choice to consumers across Europe and beyond.
Indiana Secretary of State, Connie Lawson, is leading a noble initiative to support women in need through the ‘Dress for Success’s Send One Suit’ drive.
The campaign aims to collect professional attire for women who are striving to enter or re-enter the workforce.
By hosting this drive, Secretary Lawson hopes to empower women by providing them with the necessary tools to succeed in their career endeavors.
The ‘Send One Suit’ drive encourages individuals to donate gently used professional clothing, particularly suits, to assist women in need.
These donations will help women make a positive impression during job interviews and ultimately secure employment opportunities.
Secretary Lawson emphasized the importance of dressing professionally in the workplace and how it can significantly impact a woman's confidence and success.
“These suits help empower women to take charge of their lives by giving them the confidence they need in an interview to get the job and the wardrobe to make a career change.
The suits are meant to empower women in the community to be self-sufficient and successful in work and life.
“Ultimately, these suits do more than help women get jobs; they help them move towards economic independence.

I encourage everyone to look in their closet this week to see if they have a least one suit they can donate.” Contributions can be made at the Secretary of State’s office anytime this week between 8 a.m. and 4:30 p.m.
The office is located at 200 W. Washington St. in room 201.

Dave Matthews Band has spoken out against the white nationalist violence that erupted in its hometown of Charlottesville, Virginia, calling it "cowardly and shameful."
“This is not the Charlottesville we know and love; we will work hard, hand-in-hand with our community to help us all heal from this sickening display of hate.
Hate speech disguised as free speech is cowardly and shameful.
Such speech gives permission to the hateful acts we witnessed today; there is nothing pure or acceptable, or philosophical about Nazism and racism masked as heritage or cultural purity.

As a prominent musical group with roots in Charlottesville, Dave Matthews Band's strong stance against the violence and hatred seen in their community sends a powerful message of unity and resilience in the face of bigotry.
Video A four-year-old with cancer got a special superhero surprise when some of his favourite characters turned up at his home.
Toby Nye, from Leeds, was delighted to see Spider-Man, Batman, and other superheroes arriving at his doorstep to bring joy and excitement to his day.
The young boy, who has been bravely battling cancer, was thrilled to meet his heroes in person and even got to pose for pictures with them.
The surprise visit brought a big smile to Toby's face, and his family was touched by the kindness shown to him during this challenging time.
Mum, Stacey, said he had been overwhelmed by the surprise.
"It was amazing, just out of this world.
We just never expected any of that, it was unbelievable," she said.
In a recent development, a Salvadoran man on Texas death row, Erick Davila Guevara, faced a setback as his appeal to the Supreme Court was unsuccessful.
Guevara was convicted for the fatal shootings of Tae Youk, a 48-year-old from South Korea, and Gerardo Yaxon, a 21-year-old from Guatemala, in southwest Houston back in June 2000.
Despite arguments presented by Guevara's attorneys claiming his mental impairment and ineligibility for the death penalty, the Supreme Court upheld the lower courts' rulings.
Guevara, who was identified as the shooter in the incident where he and two accomplices fled without any money, is currently without an execution date.
Attorneys for Guevara asked the justices to reverse lower courts’ rulings rejecting arguments that he’s mentally impaired and ineligible for the death penalty.
Guevara was convicted and sentenced to death for the fatal shootings of 48-year-old Tae Youk and 21-year-old Gerardo Yaxon.
Youk was from South Korea and Yaxon from Guatemala.
Guevara, identified as the shooter, and two accomplices fled the scene in southwest Houston in June 2000 without any money.
He does not yet have an execution date.
WEST MONROE, La.
(WFLA) – An 18-year-old Louisiana man faces charges for disturbing the peace after he allegedly cursed near a senior citizen.
The Ouachita Citizen reports Jared Dylan Smith was arrested on a disorderly conduct charge on April 8.

According to the report, the complaint stated: “While standing next to my 75-year-old complainant, Jared yelled the word ‘f***’ and clearly disturbed her peace.” No witnesses were present at the time.
Following the incident, Smith was taken into custody by local authorities and booked into the Ouachita Correctional Center.
His bond was set at $200.

Louisiana law defines disturbing the peace as “addressing any offensive, derisive, or annoying words to any other person who is lawfully in any street, or other public place; or call him by any offensive or derisive name, or make any noise or exclamation in his presence and hearing with the intent to deride, offend, or annoy him, or to prevent him from pursuing his lawful business, occupation, or duty.” If convicted, Smith could be fined up to $100 and may be required to spend up to 90 days in jail.

UK advertising leader, Karen Blackett, has been named the top ethnic minority executive in a recent list, showcasing her commitment to diversity and inclusion in the industry.
Ms. Blackett, who serves as the chief executive of MediaCom, the largest UK media agency, has been a trailblazer in driving positive change within her organization and the wider advertising sector.

Faced with the conglomerate’s possible break-up since the April departure of founder Sir Martin Sorrell, she is focused on “business as usual” but inclusion remains a priority: “More diverse companies are more successful and more profitable — fact,” says Ms Blackett.
The most senior black woman in UK advertising has set up the UK Inclusion Board to improve diversity at WPP.
In her five years as chief executive of MediaCom, the largest UK media agency she now chairs, the percentage of non-white staff rose from 11 to 20 per cent.
Blackett's efforts have not gone unnoticed, as she continues to champion diversity through tangible actions and initiatives.
Her leadership has led to a significant increase in the representation of non-white staff within her agency, reflecting her unwavering dedication to creating a more inclusive workplace.
As the advertising industry grapples with issues of diversity and representation, Karen Blackett stands out as a shining example of how impactful leadership can drive meaningful change.

Her position at the top of the ethnic minority executives list serves as a testament to her ongoing commitment to fostering a more diverse and inclusive environment within the UK advertising landscape.

UNITED NATIONS (AP) — A new U.N. report says migrants are sending home billions of dollars more than they did a decade ago which is helping lift their families out of poverty — and it says the rate of growth in remittances is almost double the increase in migration.
According to the report, migrants sent a record $530 billion in remittances to their home countries in 2018, a 10% increase from the previous year.
This surge in remittances is crucial for many developing countries, as the funds sent back by migrants often go towards basic needs such as food, education, and healthcare.
The report highlights the positive impact of these remittances in reducing poverty and improving the quality of life for families left behind.
Additionally, it underscores the significant contribution of migrants to the global economy through their financial support to their home countries.

TRAVERSE CITY, Mich. (AP) — Attorneys general from three states say a $275 million federal plan for keeping Asian carp from migrating into the Great Lakes is too pricey and rejects the most effective solution.
** The attorneys from Michigan, Ohio, and Wisconsin are advocating for a more aggressive approach by walling off the lakes from the Mississippi River watershed.
They argue that this method is the most efficient way to prevent the invasive species from causing irreparable harm to the Great Lakes' ecosystem.
The current plan, which includes measures such as electric barriers and underwater speakers, is deemed insufficient by the attorneys general.
The invasive Asian carp pose a significant threat to the native fish populations and could have devastating consequences for the region's fishing industry.
The attorneys are urging federal authorities to reconsider their strategy and prioritize the long-term protection of the Great Lakes.
Italy is intensifying its efforts to bring Cesare Battisti, a former member of the Armed Proletarians for Communism, to justice.
Battisti, who escaped from an Italian prison in 1981, is facing extradition demands from Italy to serve time for four murder convictions.
The Italian government has formally requested Brazil to send Battisti back to Italy to face the consequences of his alleged crimes.
A growing number of Italian lawmakers, including ex-Premier Matteo Renzi, are joining the call for Battisti's extradition.
Justice Minister Andrea Orlando has stated that extradition is possible and emphasized Italy's determination to ensure that Battisti serves his sentence.
The Italian authorities see his return as a way to provide closure and justice to the families of his victims.
A chorus of lawmakers, including ex-Premier Matteo Renzi, are demanding that Battisti finally face justice for Italian murder convictions.

Justice Minister Andrea Orlando says extradition "is possible" and that Italy is determined he serve time to "give back, at least in part, what was taken from our country and the families of his victims."
Battisti escaped from Italian prison in 1981 while awaiting trial on four counts of murder allegedly committed when he was a member of the Armed Proletarians for Communism.
He was convicted in absentia in 1990.
He has acknowledged membership in the group but denies killing anyone.
Ex-Brazilian President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva rejected extradition in 2010.
CAMPBELL RIVER, B.C- A wildfire burning near the Strathcona dam, west of Campbell River, is growing in size and is reported to be person-caused, according to the BC Wildfire Service.
The fire has been spreading rapidly due to dry conditions and strong winds in the area.
As a result, officials are urging nearby residents to stay vigilant and be prepared to evacuate if necessary.
Firefighters are working tirelessly to contain the blaze, but challenging terrain and limited access are complicating their efforts.
Helicopters and air tankers have been deployed to assist in the firefighting operation.
The BC Wildfire Service is reminding the public to exercise caution and follow all fire safety guidelines to prevent further incidents.
Local authorities are monitoring the situation closely and coordinating with emergency response teams to ensure the safety of residents and wildlife in the affected areas.
The Widnes Vikings head coach, Simon Jukes, is on a mission to turn around his team's fortunes after a string of disappointing results.

He emphasized the need for his players to be more clinical and efficient in converting chances into points.
Despite the setbacks, Jukes remains optimistic about his team's potential and believes they are capable of producing better results with some adjustments.
The recent loss to Hull FC further highlighted the team's shortcomings, with Widnes falling short by a margin of 24-10.
The defeat pushed them further away from the top eight positions in the league standings, adding more pressure on Jukes and his players to deliver improved performances.
The Centurions suffered a fifth straight loss as they went down to Hull FC 24-10, a result that saw them move further adrift of the top eight.
Jukes was left frustrated with his side’s inability to convert chances.
“I thought we created enough chances but couldn’t get the ball down,” he said.
“We need to get a little bit better across the board.

Light-duty trucks electrify the clean vehicle market Image: Fuso New light-duty electric trucks are hitting the roads in the UK, Germany, Japan and the US.

Germany, known for its strong commitment to renewable energy and sustainability, is also embracing electric light-duty trucks as part of its efforts to transition to a greener transportation sector.
The increased availability of charging infrastructure and government incentives have further accelerated the adoption of these vehicles across the country.
In Japan, renowned for its technological innovation, electric light-duty trucks are becoming a common sight on the streets.
Companies are recognizing the long-term benefits of electrification, including lower operational costs and a reduced carbon footprint.
Similarly, in the US, where the push for clean energy solutions is gaining traction, electric light-duty trucks are making a significant impact.
With advancements in battery technology and an expanding network of charging stations, more businesses are making the switch to electric trucks to support sustainability initiatives.
Overall, the rise of electric light-duty trucks signifies a positive shift towards a cleaner and more sustainable future in the global transportation industry.

In a thrilling matchup, Canisius secured a hard-fought victory over Marist with a final score of 73-67, propelled by stellar performances from Takal Molson and Isaiah Crumpton who both achieved double-doubles.
Molson, with his second double-double of the season, showcased his versatility with an impressive 18 points and 10 rebounds.
Crumpton, on the other hand, delivered a career-first double-double with a standout performance of 14 points and 12 rebounds.
The game was a seesaw battle with Marist holding the lead for most of the second half, extending it to as much as 11 points.
However, Canisius rallied back, taking the lead after a powerful dunk by Jibreel Faulkner with 5:35 left on the clock.
A crucial 8-0 run further solidified the Griffins' lead, ultimately securing their well-deserved win.
Despite Marist outshooting Canisius with a 53% to 35% field goal percentage, turnovers proved costly as they committed 24 compared to Canisius' more disciplined play.
Brian Parker of Marist also put up a strong effort with 19 points and 11 rebounds, marking his first double-double of the season.
Crumpton’s double-double is a career first; Molson’s is his second.
The Red Foxes (5-18, 3-8) had led the entire second half, by as many as 11, when Canisius took the lead on Jibreel Faulkner’s dunk with 5:35 to go.
An 8-0 spurt extended the Griffins’ lead to 71-62 with 37 seconds remaining.
Marist outshot Canisius 53 to 35 per cent but had 24 turnovers.
Brian Parker scored 19 points with 11 rebounds for Marist, his first double-double this season.

VALENCIA, Spain (AP) — The Egyptian Football Federation says Mohamed Salah's shoulder injury will not keep him out for longer than three weeks, meaning he should be fit to play at least some part in the country's World Cup campaign.
The Liverpool forward was injured in the first half of Saturday's Champions League final against Real Madrid and left the field in tears.

Liverpool manager Jurgen Klopp said after the game that Salah's World Cup campaign was in jeopardy but the EFA gave an optimistic update on Wednesday after its president Hani Abu Reda, national team coach Hector Cuper and doctor Mohamed Abou El-Ela met with the forward in Valencia, where the 25-year-old is undergoing treatment and rehabilitation.
A post on the federation's Facebook page said that "the period of absence of Salah due to injury will not exceed three weeks."
This news comes as a relief to Egyptian football fans and the national team, as Salah's presence and form have been crucial to their hopes in the upcoming World Cup in Russia.
Salah has been in exceptional form this season, breaking numerous records and winning multiple individual awards.
His absence would have been a significant blow to Egypt's chances in the tournament.
The Egyptian FA's announcement indicates that Salah is responding well to treatment and is on track for a swift recovery.
While he may miss some of Egypt's early group stage matches, the expectation is that he will be available for later games as the team progresses in the tournament.
The news has been met with widespread positivity and support from fans and teammates alike, who are eagerly anticipating Salah's return to action on the world stage.

ATCHISON COUNTY — A motorist driving on four flat tires led police on a two-hour pursuit in parts of Kansas and Missouri before his arrest.
The chase began early Thursday in northeast Kansas’ Atchison County when officers attempted to stop a pickup truck driven by 34-year-old Shane Gage on a warrant with several felony violations.
Police say Gage later drove into neighboring Missouri, through St. Joseph and toward Savannah.
During the chase, Gage's vehicle was seen swerving and driving at erratic speeds due to the flat tires, causing sparks to fly as the rims scraped against the road.

Despite the damaged tires, Gage continued to evade law enforcement through multiple jurisdictions, prompting a coordinated effort between Kansas and Missouri authorities to bring the pursuit to a safe conclusion.
After a two-hour chase, officers were able to apprehend Gage near Savannah, Missouri, where he was taken into custody without further incident.
Authorities are investigating the circumstances that led to the initial warrant and the subsequent actions of Gage during the lengthy pursuit.
The incident serves as a reminder of the dangers posed by reckless driving and the importance of cooperation between law enforcement agencies in ensuring public safety on the roads.
TOPEKA, Kan. (AP) — Republican Ron Estes plans to take his seat April 25 as the congressman representing south-central Kansas.
Estes is state treasurer and won a special election for the 4th Congressional District seat previously held by CIA Director Mike Pompeo.
Estes, a conservative Republican, is set to be sworn in next week, eager to begin serving the constituents of the 4th District.
He has expressed his commitment to upholding traditional Kansas values and working towards economic growth and job creation in the region.
The transition from his role as state treasurer to congressman is expected to be smooth, with Estes bringing his experience in financial management and conservative principles to the federal level.

He has stated that one of his top priorities will be to support policies that benefit both rural and urban communities in the district, focusing on issues such as agriculture, healthcare, and infrastructure.
Estes defeated Democrat James Thompson for the congressional seat by 7 percentage points.
The race drew national attention because Pompeo won his last three elections by more than 30 percentage points.

SKOPJE, Macedonia (AP) — Paleontologists from Bulgaria and Macedonia are excavating the fossilized remains of a prehistoric elephant believed to pre-date the mammoth, after its bones were discovered accidentally by a man working in a field.
Scientists at the Natural Science Museum of Macedonia and the Natural History Museum of Sofia said Tuesday they began excavating the skeleton in Dolni Disan in central Macedonia last Friday.
The elephant-like creature, estimated to be around 8 million years old, is providing valuable insights into the ancient fauna of the region.
The team of researchers is carefully uncovering the remains, hoping to learn more about the species, its size, and its behavior.
This discovery has sparked excitement in the scientific community, as it sheds light on the evolutionary history of elephants and other prehistoric mammals in the area.
Further analysis of the remains is expected to reveal more details about this fascinating ancient creature.
Getty Image The wildest story of the 2017-18 NBA season (which has featured plenty) came to light on a night when no basketball was being played.

The Ringer published a report from Ben Detrick about multiple Twitter burner accounts that appeared to be tied to Bryan Colangelo, which stunned NBA Twitter and caused fans, media, NBA executives, and even Joel Embiid to lose their collective minds over the possibility Colangelo was bad-mouthing his own players and other teams on secret Twitter accounts.
Nearly 24 hours after the report dropped, Sixers Twitter has been hard at work trying to determine who exactly is behind the accounts.
There’s plenty of reason to question whether Colangelo himself, ostensibly a busy man being an NBA executive, would have time to operate five separate Twitter accounts just to defend his honor.
The latest twist in this bizarre saga is the speculation that the burner accounts may actually belong to Bryan Colangelo’s wife, Barbara Bottini.

LOS ANGELES (AP) — A "Bachelor in Paradise" contestant says she's a "victim" of events that put the reality show's production on hold.
In a statement Wednesday, Corinne Olympios said she has hired an attorney to "obtain justice," in her words.
She also said she's seeking therapy to deal with what she called the physical and emotional trauma she experienced June 4.
Olympios said she has little memory of what occurred.
Following Olympios' statement, fellow contestants and members of the production crew have come forward with varying accounts of the incident.
The controversy has sparked a debate on the safety and well-being of contestants on reality TV shows.
Many are questioning the responsibility of production companies in ensuring a safe environment for participants.
Warner Bros. has said it is conducting a "thorough investigation" and "appropriate responsive action" will follow.
The studio didn't offer details on the allegations or the contestants involved.
The studio declined comment Wednesday on Olympios' statement.
A small aircraft crashed into the Yuba River near Browns Valley yesterday morning, startling nearby residents and prompting a swift response from emergency services.
The pilot, identified as Timothy Bennett, found himself in a harrowing situation as his yellow Piper Cub went down in the remote area.
Witnesses reported seeing the plane engulfed in flames before it plunged into the river.
Fortunately, the quick actions of the California Highway Patrol and CalFire helped avert a potential tragedy.

A Highway Patrol rescue helicopter received a call from CalFire about an airplane on fire and going down in Yuba County near Browns Valley around 8:30 yesterday morning… Listen to Brandon Hallam 1 The helicopter was able to land on a sand bar about 50 feet from the plane, and Flight Officer Brandon Hallam went to check on Timothy Bennett, the plane’s pilot.
Bennett was sitting on the yellow Piper Cub waving, but had an apparent broken ankle.

Hallam carried him to safety… Listen to Brandon Hallam 2 Bennett, estimated to be in his 60s, was flown a short distance to where a ground ambulance was staged, and then taken to U-C Davis Medical Center in Sacramento.
The exact cause of the crash is still under investigation.
